ECR emphasizes streamlining EUSF disbursement timelines to ensure timely aid delivery, particularly for Bulgaria’s flood recovery efforts.  
ECR applauds the issue’s fiscal responsibility through redeployment over new appropriations, perfectly reflecting their manifesto principles on efficient EU resource use.

GUE/NGL entirely promotes the swift mobilization of EU Solidarity Funds for flood relief, perfectly aligning with their commitment to prioritize vulnerable communities in crisis response.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes the critical need to maintain robust humanitarian aid levels, proposing enhanced monitoring to ensure future budgets avoid reductions in programs like UNWRA support.  
GUE/NGL strongly upholds deferring payments to 2015 as a necessary measure to protect immediate disaster response capabilities while urging accelerated implementation of social cohesion mechanisms.  
GUE/NGL applauds the issue’s alignment with anti-austerity principles through its refusal to impose additional cuts on essential public services during reconstruction efforts.  
GUE/NGL highlights the urgency of addressing regional inequalities through this intervention, calling for strengthened transparency in tracking cohesion fund allocations to prevent future payment backlogs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to mobilize the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for €79,726,440 in commitment and payment appropriations to address flood damage in Serbia and Croatia (May 2014) and Bulgaria (June 2014), formalizing this adjustment in the 2014 budget. It stressed the critical shortage of 2014 payment appropriations, which precluded redeployment of funds and necessitated shifting corresponding payment needs to the 2015 budget. The resolution endorsed the Joint Conclusions of 8 December 2014, approving an additional €80 million in 2014 commitment appropriations while deferring payments, and approved the Council’s position on Draft Amending Budget No 7/2014. It finalized the adoption of Amending Budget No 6/2014, emphasizing swift disbursement of aid and instructing its publication in the Official Journal to ensure legal effect.

title: Draft amending budget No 8/2014: Surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 8/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: The 2013 EU budget implementation generated a €1.005 billion surplus from higher-than-expected income (fines, interest) and under-spent appropriations amid payment shortages. EU financial rules mandate surplus allocation through amending budgets. The Parliament will discuss redistributing the 2013 surplus in line with budgetary procedures.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely agrees the surplus reallocation mechanism as a model of budgetary discipline, perfectly aligning with their commitment to responsible financial governance under Article 18 of the Financial Regulation.  
EPP applauds the issue's prevention of national appropriation of EU-level fines and interest revenues, reinforcing their principle of collective fiscal responsibility among Member States.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for structured debt repayment plans to address residual unpaid bills, proposing enhanced Commission monitoring to accelerate backlog clearance while maintaining current payment ceilings.  
EPP strongly endorses the issue's avoidance of provisional twelfths budgets as essential for preserving SME funding and Erasmus continuity, key priorities in their growth agenda.  
EPP highlights the Juncker Plan's synergy with this budgetary approach while advocating safeguards to prevent innovation program depletion, ensuring Horizon 2020 remains fully resourced for competitiveness goals.

EFDD conditionally supports the surplus reallocation but demands structural reforms to prevent recurring payment crises, citing unresolved €20+ billion liabilities.  
EFDD firmly disapproves increased GNI-based contributions, arguing this perpetuates unfair fiscal burdens inconsistent with national sovereignty principles.  
EFDD requests audit mechanisms for all reallocated funds, referencing systemic corruption in Italian reception centers as evidence of current oversight failures.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of budgetary credibility by maintaining the "political commitments over payments" approach EFDD explicitly condemns.  
EFDD warns this temporary fix contradicts their core stance against EU financial integration, emphasizing 58% UK exit sentiment as symptomatic of systemic distrust.

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the surplus reallocation as perfectly aligning with fiscal responsibility principles, ensuring Member States’ contributions reflect actual budgetary needs.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s compatibility with climate resilience priorities by proposing enhanced future allocations to preventive cohesion projects addressing extreme weather impacts.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need to stabilize payment systems through this agreement while advocating accelerated reforms to eliminate structural payment backlogs.  
GREEN_EFA applauds strict adherence to Article 18 of the Financial Regulation as foundational to transparent surplus management across EU institutions.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s role in maintaining budgetary continuity while urging intensified negotiations to resolve systemic payment appropriation shortfalls.

ALDE firmly accepts the issue's allocation of the 2013 surplus to reduce Member States' contributions, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to fiscal responsibility and equitable burden-sharing.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s adherence to Article 18 of the Financial Regulation, reinforcing ALDE’s longstanding advocacy for strict budgetary discipline and procedural compliance.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need to address unpaid EU obligations through enhanced debt settlement mechanisms, as highlighted by Jean Arthuis, to safeguard the Union’s credibility and operational integrity.  
ALDE strongly approves the issue’s corrective action to overcome the Conciliation Committee’s deadlock, advancing ALDE’s priority of institutional efficiency in budget negotiations.  
ALDE urges sustained focus on apuring legacy payment arrears, as outlined in the issue, to ensure future budgetary frameworks prevent recurrent liquidity crises.

SD absolutely advocates the issue's alignment with fiscal responsibility through surplus reallocation to reduce national contributions, perfectly matching SD's commitment to equitable burden-sharing among Member States.  
SD applauds the issue's adherence to Financial Regulation Article 18 as a model for budgetary discipline, advancing SD's priority of transparent EU financial governance.  
SD highlights the necessity of ongoing payment monitoring (as raised in debates) as an enhancement opportunity to strengthen implementation credibility for future budgets.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s congruence with European solidarity principles by preventing disproportionate GNI-based levies, directly reflecting SD’s manifesto goals for fair economic integration.  
SD underscores the urgency of addressing payment backlog root causes through this issue’s framework, aligning with SD’s persistent advocacy for operational budget efficiency.

ECR fundamentally promotes the surplus reallocation mechanism as a model application of fiscal responsibility principles central to ECR's budgetary philosophy.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's strict adherence to Article 18 Financial Regulation compliance, reinforcing ECR's constitutionalist approach to EU finance governance.  
ECR proposes strengthening future surplus frameworks through accelerated debt clearance protocols to address historical payment arrears noted in debate interventions.  
ECR applauds the €1.005 billion GNI contribution reduction as exemplifying ECR's core objective of returning fiscal sovereignty to member states.  
ECR highlights the issue's systemic value in preventing 2015 budgetary imbalances through rigorous 2013 surplus absorption, aligning with ECR's multi-annual budget stabilization agenda.

GUE/NGL strongly agrees the reallocation of the 2013 surplus to reduce Member States' contributions, aligning with their commitment to equitable fiscal responsibility and alleviating undue financial burdens on nations.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes the necessity of addressing future structural deficits through enhanced cohesion funding and sustainable resource solutions to prevent recurring budgetary shortfalls.  
GUE/NGL proposes reinforcing transparency mechanisms to ensure redirected funds prioritize social cohesion and public welfare, particularly in sectors like fisheries and education disproportionately impacted by austerity.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue’s partial alignment with anti-austerity principles but urges accelerated efforts to reverse systemic underfunding of critical programs such as UNWRA and Erasmus+.  
GUE/NGL approves the surplus reallocation as a pragmatic step toward fiscal justice while advocating for broader treaty reforms to counteract divergences exacerbated by current budgetary constraints.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to address the 2013 budget surplus of €1,005 million, comprising €771 million in unanticipated income (primarily from fines and interest on late payments totaling €1,331 million, offset by declines in collected own resources and surpluses), €276 million in underspent expenditures due to insufficient payment appropriations in 2012 and 2013 (€107 million and €54 million respectively), and a €42 million exchange rate loss. It approved Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 8/2014, which reallocates this surplus to reduce Member States’ GNI-based contributions to the EU budget by €1,005 million, partially offsetting their obligations under related DABs. The resolution highlighted that DAB No 8/2014 was necessitated by the failure of the Conciliation Committee to agree on DAB No 2/2014 (identical in purpose) amid broader disputes over 2014 payment needs and the interconnected DAB package (Nos 3-7/2014). By endorsing the Council’s position, Parliament finalized the adoption of the amending budget, emphasizing compliance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation, which mandates surplus incorporation into the budget.

title: Control of the Register and composition of the Commission's expert groups: REPORT on control of the Register and composition of the Commission’s expert groups
background: The European Commission's 2016 expert group rules followed prior concerns over transparency and stakeholder balance, including 2011/2014 budgetary reserves, a 2016 study identifying imbalances, and European Ombudsman recommendations. The Parliament will discuss oversight of expert group composition and transparency mechanisms under the Commission's revised framework.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on transparency and balanced composition of expert groups, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and equitable stakeholder representation.  
ECR approves the mandate for systematic publication of expert group agendas, minutes, and dissenting opinions, which advances ECR’s priority of ensuring traceable and participatory policymaking.  
ECR proposes amending Section 4 to explicitly define “balanced composition” criteria tied to sectoral impact assessments, ensuring underrepresented groups like SMEs receive proportional representation.  
ECR applauds the call for financial support mechanisms to facilitate participation of non-economic stakeholders, a measure consistent with ECR’s advocacy for inclusive governance.  
ECR urges strict adherence to the June 2017 deadline for the Commission’s implementation report, emphasizing this as critical to resolving persistent imbalances noted since 2013.

GUE_NGL firmly advocates the issue's emphasis on transparency as perfectly aligning with their foundational principle of citizen-centric governance.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with demands for systematic civil society inclusion, proposing enhanced consultation mechanisms to institutionalize participatory democracy.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's critical role in preventing institutional detachment, noting its provisions effectively advance accountability to marginalized communities.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the issue's call for financial support to underrepresented groups as vital to rebalancing corporate-dominated policy spaces.  
GUE_NGL asserts the linkage between expert group transparency and public trust directly mirrors their decades-long advocacy for open decision-making processes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over transparency and imbalanced composition in the European Commission’s expert groups (EGs), noting that 9% of EGs remained imbalanced since 2013 despite prior reforms. While welcoming the Commission’s 2016 Decision introducing horizontal rules for EGs—including public calls for expert selection, conflict-of-interest declarations, and improved registers—Parliament criticized the lack of a full public consultation during the reform process. It emphasized the need for balanced representation of economic and non-economic interests, urging clearer criteria for defining "balanced composition" tied to each EG’s mandate and stakeholder impact. Parliament called for greater transparency by publishing agendas, minutes, and dissenting opinions from EG meetings, aligning with the European Ombudsman’s recommendations, and stressed the need for financial support to facilitate participation of underrepresented groups (e.g., SMEs, trade unions). It demanded the Commission address persistent imbalances, ensure systematic oversight of EG rules, and submit an implementation report by June 2017. Additionally, Parliament highlighted the link between transparency, public trust, and regulatory legitimacy, urging the Commission to align EG practices with interinstitutional agreements and improve accessibility of policy documents via updated registers.

title: Draft amending budget No 2/2014 - surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 2/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: The 2013 EU budget execution generated a €1.005 billion surplus from fines, under-spending, and exchange adjustments, alongside €23.4 billion in unpaid commitments from previous years. The Parliament will discuss allocating the surplus and addressing 2014 payment shortages within budgetary procedures.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue's technical adjustment of allocating the 2013 surplus to reduce Member States' contributions, aligning with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and institutional trust-building.  
EPP applauds the procedural linkage of DAB 2/2014 with subsequent budgets as a rational approach to balance revenue adjustments and payment obligations, mirroring their manifesto priorities for budgetary stability.  
EPP emphasizes the Council's obligation to honor its formal declarations on amending budgets, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure future compliance with agreed payment schedules.  
EPP approves the issue's distinction between payment shortages and absorption capacity issues, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for accurate budgetary diagnostics in cohesion policy implementation.  
EPP highlights the need for supplementary measures beyond DAB 2/2014 to comprehensively address structural payment gaps, while fully endorsing this interim step's alignment with multiannual financial framework principles.

EFDD slightly upholds the surplus reallocation but requests binding commitments to resolve the €20 billion payment backlog before approving any contribution reductions  
EFDD firmly againsts linking DAB 2/2014 to subsequent budgets without ironclad guarantees for honoring existing payment obligations first  
The proposal's procedural interdependence fails to address EFDD's core concern about chronic underfunding of implemented programs from 2012-2013  
EFDD demands amendment of Article 5 to include mandatory quarterly reporting on legacy debt clearance before authorizing GNI contribution adjustments  
 While supporting surplus redistribution, EFDD rejects the assumption that €106 million net increase sufficiently addresses systemic payment capacity flaws

GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the interdependent adoption of Draft Amending Budgets 2/2014, 3/2014, and 4/2014 as critical to maintaining fiscal equilibrium, perfectly aligning with their commitment to responsible budgetary governance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on procedural coherence, stressing that linking these budgets ensures Member States honor financial commitments in line with the principle of *pacta sunt servanda*.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the Council’s untenable position on debt payments as a pivotal reason to adopt the unamended issue, reinforcing their stance that supranational agreements must be upheld without exception.  
This issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA’s priority of equitable fiscal burden-sharing by redistributing surpluses to reduce GNI contributions while safeguarding EU payment capacities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s rejection of absorption-related narratives, framing under-implementation as a systemic payment failure that demands strict adherence to the proposed budgetary adjustments.

ALDE strongly upholds the utilization of the 2013 surplus to offset Member States’ GNI contributions, aligning with ALDE's commitment to fiscal efficiency and equitable burden-sharing.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the Court of Justice’s capacity through expedited judicial appointments to address competition case backlogs, ensuring fines reflect deterrence rather than systemic market failures.  
ALDE approves the procedural linkage of DABs 2/2014, 3/2014, and 4/2014 as a balanced mechanism to reconcile revenue adjustments with payment obligations.  
ALDE emphasizes that resolving hidden debt from commitment-payment gaps must remain a strategic priority, consistent with their advocacy for transparent budgetary governance.  
ALDE commends the distinction between payment shortages and absorption capacity issues, reinforcing accountability in budget implementation.

SD entirely approves the issue's allocation of the 2013 surplus to reduce Member States' contributions, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to fiscal responsibility while honoring EU payment obligations.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's procedural linkage of all three DABs, recognizing this interdependence as essential to resolving chronic payment shortages in line with SD's demands for budgetary integrity.  
SD emphasizes that the issue's approach to under-implementation as a payment crisis rather than absorption failure directly advances SD's longstanding priority of protecting beneficiaries of EU programs.  
SD highlights the issue's balanced revenue-expenditure adjustments as exemplifying financial accountability, mirroring SD's insistence on using fines and interest income to offset member state burdens.  
SD underscores the issue's alignment with SD's manifesto pledge to combat "backdoor austerity" by preventing unpaid commitments from undermining agreed EU policy objectives.

GUE_NGL slightly endorses the surplus reallocation in DAB No 2/2014 but requests revisions to Article 3 to prioritize reinvestment in underfunded social and regional programs over reducing GNI contributions.  
GUE_NGL highlights that the issue’s focus on lowering Member States’ payments totally doubts with their principle that austerity-driven under-implementation disproportionately harms public services, citing the €51 million shortfall in Ireland’s Social and Regional Development Funds.  
GUE_NGL demands amendments to redirect €1,005 million to emergency grants for SMEs and research institutions, noting the issue’s failure to address the human cost of payment delays, such as job losses in vulnerable sectors.  
GUE_NGL opposes the procedural linkage to DAB No 3/2014’s €3.17 billion additional payments, arguing it entrenches fiscal austerity inconsistent with their demand for debt relief to avert cuts in education and healthcare.  
GUE_NGL insists the Council include a clause mandating impact assessments on employment and public infrastructure degradation caused by chronic under-implementation, as raised in the €107 million 2013 underspend.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to address the 2013 budget surplus of €1,005 million, comprising €771 million in higher-than-expected income (primarily from fines and interest totaling €1,331 million), €276 million in expenditure under-spending, and a €42 million negative exchange rate difference. It noted declines in collected own resources (-€226 million) and surpluses, balances, and adjustments revenue (-€360 million), while emphasizing that under-implementation of 2013 (€107 million) and 2012 (€54 million) appropriations reflected payment shortages rather than absorption issues. The resolution linked Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 2/2014, which allocates the surplus to reduce Member States’ GNI contributions by €1,005 million, to DAB No 3/2014 (requiring €3,170 million in additional payments) and DAB No 4/2014 (providing €2,059 million in own resources). It highlighted that adopting all three unamended would result in a net increase of only €106 million in Member States’ GNI contributions to cover 2014 payment obligations, stressing the procedural interdependence of these budgets to balance revenue and expenditure adjustments.

title: Draft amending budget No 3/2014: Revenue from fines, interest payments, reimbursements and repayments – Payment appropriations – Establishment plans of the Commission, the Committee of the Regions and the European Data Protection Supervisor: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 3/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: Persistent payment backlogs from prior EU programming periods, compounded by the transition to the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework, created pressure to reconcile existing financial obligations with constrained payment appropriations amid member states’ fiscal consolidation efforts. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to the 2014 budget addressing revenue revisions and payment allocation to manage outstanding commitments.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the adoption of Draft Amending Budget No 3/2014 as critical to stabilizing EU payment credibility and preventing budgetary collapse, aligning with its commitment to fiscal responsibility and growth-oriented policies.  
EPP emphasizes the urgent need for a structural solution to chronic payment backlogs under Heading 1b, urging the Commission to propose binding multiyear plans to eliminate unpaid bills while safeguarding cohesion policy implementation.  
EPP applauds the mobilization of the Contingency Margin to address immediate liquidity needs, which aligns with its advocacy for leveraging MFF flexibility to protect programs like Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+.  
EPP proposes enhancing transparency in communicating fines and national contribution adjustments to avoid public misinterpretation of EU fiscal mechanisms.  
EPP fundamentally accepts the issue’s focus on reducing Member States’ GNI contributions through responsible budget amendments, reinforcing its vision of a financially sustainable EU.

EFDD slightly promotes the payment appropriations but highlights structural failures in addressing systemic corruption risks within cohesion fund allocations, particularly citing Italian regional scandals where both left and right-wing parties misused immigration-related funds.  
EFDD requests revisions to the Contingency Margin activation framework, arguing it institutionalizes temporary fixes inconsistent with EFDD’s demand for permanent solutions to payment backlogs rooted in flawed MFF flexibility rules.  
EFDD opposes the issue’s reliance on increased GNI contributions, which firmly opposes with EFDD’s stance against centralized fiscal policies and growing public dissent in states like the UK, where 58% now favor EU exit due to perceived inequitable burdens.  
EFDD criticizes the omission of binding safeguards to prevent recurring payment crises, noting the issue’s 70% allocation to Heading 1b merely perpetuates a cycle of debt accumulation that harms national businesses and administrations.  
EFDD demands rigorous audit requirements for Sardinia’s flood reconstruction funds, emphasizing that unchecked regional corruption – a recurring EFDD concern – undermines solidarity mechanisms unless paired with real-time spending transparency.

GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue's urgent mobilization of the Contingency Margin to address payment shortfalls, perfectly aligning with their fiscal responsibility principles in cohesion policy implementation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's critique of Council reservations on MFF flexibility, emphasizing this as critical to preventing further erosion of trust in EU budgetary commitments.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the prioritization of Heading 1b allocations while urging accelerated structural reforms to permanently resolve payment backlogs consistent with their sustainable development agenda.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for regular payment backlog reporting, proposing enhanced transparency through public dashboards tracking project-specific disbursement timelines.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes linking future budget negotiations to climate resilience investments, as emphasized in debate contributions about flood prevention and Cohesion Policy synergies.

ALDE strongly promotes the reinforcement of payment appropriations through DAB No 3/2014 as a critical step to address the unsustainable backlog in Cohesion policy payments, aligning with ALDE's commitment to fiscal responsibility and operational credibility.  
ALDE urges the Commission to prioritize structural reforms of the Multiannual Financial Framework instruments, particularly full activation of the Contingency Margin as intended by MFF Regulation Article 13, to prevent recurring liquidity crises.  
ALDE proposes enhancing transparency through quarterly reports on payment arrears under Heading 1b, ensuring real-time monitoring of backlog evolution and adherence to 90-day payment deadlines for beneficiaries.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on reducing Member States’ GNI contributions through recovered fines and interest, which aligns with ALDE’s manifesto goals of equitable burden-sharing and efficient budget execution.  
ALDE calls for immediate solidarity measures to address emergency funding needs in flood-affected regions like Bulgaria, Croatia, and Serbia, reinforcing cohesion policy’s role in crisis response as outlined in the issue.

SD strongly advocates the reinforcement of payment appropriations through the Contingency Margin, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to urgent fiscal solidarity and addressing Cohesion policy shortfalls exacerbated since 2010.  
SD applauds the issue’s prioritization of Heading 1b allocations as a critical step to mitigate immediate payment crises, effectively advancing SD’s manifesto goals to safeguard EU-funded social and infrastructural projects.  
SD proposes enhancing regular reporting mechanisms on payment deadline compliance and backlog evolution under Heading 1b, ensuring transparency aligns with SD’s accountability principles while fully endorsing the issue’s adoption.  
SD underscores the necessity for the Commission to expedite long-term structural solutions, including full utilization of MFF instruments, to transform this interim measure into sustainable fiscal governance consistent with SD’s reform agenda.  
SD emphasizes unconditional support for reducing GNI contributions through subsequent amendments, which directly aligns with SD’s advocacy for equitable Member State burden-sharing and budgetary fairness.

ECR partly upholds the payment appropriations but highlights the issue's failure to structurally address the EUR 23.4 billion backlog, totally disputeing with their principle of fiscal responsibility.  
ECR opposes the proposed use of the Contingency Margin for agricultural compensations, citing irresponsibility in diverting crisis reserves while Russia’s food embargo persists.  
ECR rejects reliance on temporary financial instruments like the Contingency Margin, deeming it inconsistent with their demand for permanent budget reforms to prevent recurring deficits.  
ECR demands binding timelines to eliminate payment backlogs, criticizing the issue’s EUR 4.2 billion increase as insufficient against EUR 30 billion in unpaid obligations.  
ECR condemns the budget process’s complexity as Orwellian non-transparency, requiring simplification to align with their manifesto commitment to accountable spending.

GUE_NGL fully condemns the issue's failure to reverse austerity-driven budget cuts that perpetuate North-South economic disparities, directly contradicting their anti-neoliberal principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the inadequate allocation to Cohesion Policy (Heading 1b) as institutionalizing structural underfunding of regional development, exacerbating inequalities between member states.  
GUE_NGL condemns the 4.5% reduction in humanitarian aid under Heading 4 as morally indefensible given worsening refugee crises, violating their commitment to international solidarity.  
GUE_NGL denounces the Juncker Plan's diversion of payment appropriations from social programs as prioritizing financial market interests over public welfare needs.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's payment backlog "solution" fraudulent for relying on temporary contingency margins rather than addressing systemic underfunding of EU public services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the substantial payment backlog in the EU budget, particularly under Heading 1b (Cohesion policy), which reached EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013, exceeding initial forecasts and risking further growth. It endorsed Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 3/2014, which proposed reinforcing payment appropriations by EUR 4,246 million for 2014, including EUR 3,168 million mobilized through the Contingency Margin to address urgent payment needs across budget headings. The resolution highlighted that over 70% of the allocated funds under DAB No 3/2014 would target Heading 1b, though this was deemed the minimum required to address immediate shortfalls, not a structural solution to the recurring backlog exacerbated by unpaid bills since 2010. It stressed the need for unconditional and swift adoption of DAB No 3/2014, noting its impact on the 2015 budget and the broader reduction of Member States’ GNI contributions by EUR 8,688 million through subsequent amendments. The Parliament criticized Council reservations on using the Contingency Margin as contradictory to the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Regulation’s flexibility intent and urged the Commission to propose long-term solutions, including full utilization of MFF instruments and regular reporting on payment deadlines and backlog evolution under Heading 1b.

title: Amendment of the MFF 2014-2020: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014/2020
background: Delays in adopting the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Regulation and subsequent legislative acts caused late approval of 300 operational programs, risking €21.1 billion in uncommitted 2014 funds under shared management. The Parliament will discuss amending the MFF to reallocate unused appropriations and prevent financial losses.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely accepts the MFF amendment as perfectly aligning with its commitment to efficient EU fund utilization, particularly praising the €21 billion carry-forward mechanism that prevents resource loss while maintaining fiscal discipline.  
EPP perfectly aligns with provisions ensuring structural funds' continuity, emphasizing their critical role in job creation and economic cohesion across European regions as highlighted in multiple interventions.  
EPP fully supports prioritizing asylum and internal security funds through this revision, recognizing their heightened importance in addressing migration challenges and counter-terrorism needs per current geopolitical realities.  
EPP endorses the urgency of operational programme adoption timelines, transforming concerns about bureaucratic delays into a mandate for enhanced Commission-Member State collaboration to accelerate implementation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with safeguarding rural development allocations, converting Petir’s emphasis on village sustainability into an imperative for uninterrupted agricultural fund access to preserve Europe’s rural fabric.

EFDD partly sanctions the MFF adjustment while maintaining fundamental opposition to EU budgetary centralization, as articulated in Jonathan Arnott's critique that "Brussels sends it back... we could achieve better results through national financing".  
EFDD requests revisions to Article 5 provisions on Cohesion Fund allocations, arguing the current structure "drains financial resources from Member States" contrary to subsidiarity principles outlined in their 2014 electoral manifesto.  
This proposal conflicts with EFDD's core position that regional development "should be managed nationally" rather than through EU mechanisms, as Marco Zanni emphasized regarding Italy's need for localized resource allocation.  
The issue overlooks critical EFDD concerns about systemic inefficiency, evidenced by Arnott's calculation that €20 billion in lapsed commitments represents wasted taxpayer funds requiring structural reimbursement reforms.  
EFDD's partial approval remains inconsistent with their broader rejection of EU fiscal integration, as Zanni noted regarding "rash adjustments" mirroring Italy's problematic administrative practices rather than delivering genuine reform.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the MFF amendment, aligning perfectly with their commitment to responsible fiscal governance and quality-driven EU fund utilization.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on addressing implementation delays, effectively advancing their priority of streamlining bureaucracy to prioritize project outcomes over administrative complexity.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 4 oversight mechanisms to mandate robust national control systems, minimizing errors while preserving the amendment’s core objectives.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes vigilance in monitoring payment allocations to prevent future budgetary strain, urging the Commission to proactively address liquidity risks without opposing the adaptation.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s consistency with their manifesto pledge to combat financial mismanagement, particularly in safeguarding transparency for shared management programmes.

ALDE strongly sanctions the amendment as essential to ensuring EU funds reach citizens, aligning with ALDE’s commitment to responsive financial frameworks that combat economic crises through cohesion policy.  
ALDE proposes streamlining fund disbursement procedures to eliminate bureaucratic delays, enhancing trust in EU mechanisms while fully endorsing the issue’s goal of honoring commitments.  
ALDE emphasizes protecting Horizon 2020 and interconnection funds as non-negotiable future investments, urging adjusted payment ceilings to avoid sacrificing innovation-driven programs.  
ALDE highlights cohesion policy’s irreplaceable role in crisis recovery, urging reinforced allocations to match ALDE’s solidarity principles and macroeconomic stabilization priorities.  
ALDE approves the MFF revision for enabling timely budgetary execution, critical to job creation and infrastructure growth, while advocating accelerated project validation to prevent recurring underspending.

SD completely advocates the MFF amendment to reallocate €21 billion, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preventing fund expiration and ensuring full utilization of cohesion policy resources.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s urgency in avoiding payment delays, emphasizing its critical role in safeguarding employment projects like Cornwall’s Youth Employment Initiative from bureaucratic stagnation.  
SD fully supports the technical adjustment as foundational to accelerating operational programmes, directly advancing their priority of reducing regional disparities through timely structural fund deployment.  
SD highlights the amendment’s necessity to correct institutional delays in programme adoption, which aligns with their manifesto goal of streamlining EU fund accessibility for local authorities.  
SD endorses the Council Regulation revision as a vital step toward mitigating "payment peaks," thereby reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for predictable, socially impactful EU budgeting.

ECR strongly accepts the MFF amendment's budget flexibility measures, which align perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to efficient fiscal management and timely execution of cohesion policy programs.  
ECR approves the accelerated implementation timeline for operational programs, particularly noting its importance for Greek agricultural recovery and migration crisis response, while proposing enhanced Commission oversight to prevent external political interference in fund disbursement.  
ECR highlights the amendment's critical role in addressing regional depopulation in Bulgaria, urging strict application of Article 174 TFEU to prioritize territories with severe demographic decline during mid-term budget reviews.  
ECR endorses the €21 billion commitment transfer as essential for maintaining investment continuity in Central European states, effectively advancing ECR's priority of balanced economic development across all EU regions.  
ECR welcomes the extended funding window for structural projects but emphasizes the need to safeguard national budgetary autonomy during future MFF revisions.

GUE/NGL strongly agrees the Youth Guarantee fund reallocation as aligning perfectly with their commitment to combating youth unemployment through urgent social investments and anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL endorses the MFF flexibility mechanism to address implementation delays, particularly in agricultural payments, recognizing its role in advancing responsive EU budgetary governance.  
GUE/NGL proposes enhancing the issue by significantly increasing EU and national funding for public R&D, social infrastructure, and cooperative economies to ensure sustainable employment beyond temporary measures.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes that true EU cohesion requires binding commitments to eliminate regional disparities, urging alignment of budgetary tools with concrete anti-austerity funding increases.  
GUE/NGL applauds the focus on youth-centric policies while advocating for accelerated procedural reforms to maximize fund distribution efficiency across all sectors.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council Regulation (05479/2015) amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 to adjust the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2014-2020, as outlined in the annexed resolution, under the legal bases of Article 312 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Euratom Treaty. This decision formalized the Parliament’s approval of the MFF revision, enabling the updated budgetary framework to proceed, and instructed its President to communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, concluding the legislative process for the amendment.

title: Annual report on the control of the financial activities of the European Investment Bank for 2015: REPORT on the annual report on the control of the financial activities of the EIB for 2015

The Parliament will discuss the EIB's financial activities, alignment with EU policy objectives, and institutional accountability mechanisms during its annual review.

stances.stance:

EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's SME focus, strongly approveing initiatives that allocated 36.6% of EIB funding to SMEs, which they recognize as vital for job creation and economic resilience.  
EPP firmly agrees enhanced transparency and tax compliance measures, reflecting their insistence on public project assessments and strict anti-fraud protocols to uphold EU fiscal standards.  
EPP strongly approves the strategic deployment of EFSI to mobilize high-impact investments, applauding its €115.7 billion mobilization while advocating for broader sectoral and regional distribution to maximize cohesion.  
EPP firmly agrees technical assistance prioritization for underdeveloped regions, perfectly aligning with the issue’s goals to strengthen project preparedness and accelerate sustainable convergence.

EFDD rejects the issue's inadequate transparency mechanisms for EIB infrastructure projects, fully challengeing with their demand for absolute disclosure of procurement details and independent ex-post evaluations.  
EFDD opposes the issue's silence on Brexit-related financial risks, directly contradicting their insistence on repatriating UK capital and rejecting joint liabilities for eurozone structural failures.  
The proposal overlooks EFDD's imperative to block EIB funding for projects under corruption investigations like the Mestre bypass, violating their anti-fraud principles.  
EFDD fully challenges with the issue's capital expansion demands, deeming them economically reckless given the EIB's disproportionate exposure to fiscally unstable eurozone economies.  
The issue fails to address governance collusion risks, opposing EFDD's strict requirements to eliminate conflicts of interest between EIB leadership and financial markets.

ENF absolutely disapproves the issue's emphasis on correcting geographical funding imbalances, asserting that concentrated investments in core economies maximize EU competitiveness.  
ENF rejects the phase-out of gas infrastructure investments, arguing they remain critical for energy transition despite climate targets.  
ENF condemns increased transparency requirements as bureaucratic overreach that stifles the EIB’s agility in financing high-impact SMEs.  
ENF challenges governance reforms, advocating instead for direct ECB project financing to bypass market dependencies as proposed by Jean-Luc Schaffhauser.  
ENF contends the issue’s social cohesion targets undermine strategic priorities like climate innovation and cross-border infrastructure.

GREEN_EFA fully agrees the issue's imperative to phase out gas infrastructure investments, perfectly aligning with their mandate for rapid decarbonization under the Paris Agreement.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for fossil fuel lending cessation, urging accelerated adoption of binding timelines to prevent stranded assets and carbon lock-in.  
GREEN_EFA fully agrees enhanced transparency in project assessments, which directly advances their advocacy for scrutinizing energy investments against climate neutrality goals.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s climate coherence in prioritizing renewables over transitional fuels, mirroring their 2015 manifesto against gas dependency.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports cross-border additionality criteria that exclude fossil infrastructure, ensuring EIB lending catalyses systemic energy transition.

ALDE absolutely promotes the issue's climate finance targets, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to achieving 35% climate action funding by 2020 through renewable energy and decarbonized transport systems.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the phase-out of fossil fuel infrastructure investments, emphasizing the critical need to prioritize renewable energy projects and circular economy models as stated in ALDE's sustainability agenda.  
ALDE applauds the focus on enhancing EIB transparency through public project assessments, which directly advances ALDE's governance reform priorities and anti-fraud standards.  
ALDE emphasizes rigorous adherence to additionality principles for cross-border projects, reflecting ALDE's strategic vision for pan-European integration and risk-balanced investments.  
ALDE supports strengthening SME financing mechanisms across all regions, aligning perfectly with ALDE's growth strategy to reduce economic disparities through job-creating initiatives.

SD strongly promotes the issue’s focus on correcting geographical imbalances in EIB funding, aligning with SD’s commitment to cohesion and equitable development. Proposes enhancing technical assistance for underfunded regions to improve project design capacity.  
SD approves the call for transparency reforms and urges stricter conflict-of-interest protocols, reflecting SD’s priority for accountable governance. Suggests expanding Vice-President diversity to include underrepresented Member States.  
SD endorses the emphasis on SME financing but recommends raising the 38% allocation target to better reflect their 99% share in EU economies, aligning with SD’s manifesto on inclusive growth.  
SD applauds the prioritization of sustainable infrastructure and tax compliance, which advance SD’s climate justice and anti-evasion principles. Proposes accelerating gas phase-out timelines to avoid stranded assets.  
SD supports leveraging EFSI to address investment deficits, echoing SD’s economic priorities. Advocates for integrated territorial strategies to maximize cross-border cohesion impacts.

ECR strongly sanctions the issue’s prioritization of SME financing and job creation, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to fostering economic growth and innovation across EU member states.  
ECR approves the focus on cohesion through greenfield investments in newer EU countries, urging expanded expert training programs to ensure equitable access to funding and maximize developmental impact.  
ECR proposes enhancing transparency in cross-border project assessments and implementing stricter oversight on executive compensation to prevent conflicts of interest, ensuring accountability aligns with EU governance standards.

GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the discharge due to the issue's endorsement of defense sector investments, contradicting their staunch commitment to national neutrality and peace.  
GUE/NGL rejects the promotion of speculative financial instruments like PPPs and securitization, which institutionalize the privatization of profits and socialization of losses, directly conflicting with their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s alignment with EU migration policies that outsource border control to non-EU states, violating fundamental rights and perpetuating humanitarian crises, inconsistent with their advocacy for refugee protections.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address the EIB’s lack of additionality, particularly regarding the Juncker Plan’s overstated impact, which mirrors their critique of neoliberal investment frameworks.  
GUE/NGL underscores the issue’s inadequate transparency measures, notably omitting binding anti-fraud protocols and World Bank-level governance standards, thereby enabling conflicts of interest and corporate capture.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities regarding the European Investment Bank’s (EIB) activities, emphasizing its role in advancing EU integration, economic cohesion, and sustainable growth. In 2015, the EIB signed €77.5 billion in operations, with €69.7 billion allocated to EU Member States and €7.8 billion outside the EU, though 73% of EU funding was concentrated in six countries, highlighting geographical imbalances. The resolution stressed the need for greater transparency, accountability, and alignment with EU policies, including the Europe 2020 strategy, climate goals (noting €3.4 billion for renewables), and social cohesion, where the EIB fell short of its 30% target (achieving 25.2%). It called for enhanced support for SMEs, which received 36.6% of funding (leveraging €39.7 billion and supporting 5 million jobs), and urged wider adoption of the SME Initiative, active in six countries with €8.5 billion in favorable loans. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was noted for mobilizing €115.7 billion in investments by 2018, though geographical and sectoral disparities required correction. The Parliament urged the EIB to prioritize additionality, riskier projects with cross-border impact, and environmental sustainability, while phasing out gas infrastructure investments to avoid stranded assets. Transparency improvements were demanded, including public access to project assessments, anti-fraud measures, and alignment with EU tax compliance standards. Concerns were raised about governance, conflicts of interest, and the need for stricter oversight, including collaboration with the European Court of Auditors and Ombudsman. The resolution also highlighted the EIB’s role in global challenges like migration and called for strengthened cooperation with national authorities and EU funds to boost cohesion, innovation, and infrastructure, particularly in underdeveloped regions.

title: 2016 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: In 2015, the EU faced a migration influx, economic recovery challenges, agricultural market disruptions from the Russian embargo, and heightened security needs following terrorist attacks. The Parliament will discuss finalizing the 2016 EU budget, prioritizing migration management, economic growth, and internal security within existing financial constraints.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally accepts the 2016 budget's strategic mobilization of €1.5 billion via the Flexibility Instrument, perfectly aligning with their commitment to reinforcing EU security infrastructure and global crisis response capabilities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of Horizon 2020 and COSME funding increases, recognizing these programs as critical drivers of innovation and SME competitiveness in line with their economic growth agenda.  
EPP fully supports the institutional staffing adjustments that strengthen judicial oversight through the Court of Justice while maintaining fiscal discipline via Parliament's post reductions, reflecting balanced governance priorities.  
EPP endorses the budget's targeted payment appropriations for youth employment initiatives, effectively advancing their manifesto pledge to combat radicalization through opportunity creation and social inclusion.  
EPP perfectly aligns with measures to optimize EU agency efficiency, proposing enhanced interinstitutional coordination to reduce bureaucratic delays while fully implementing migration-related operational budgets.

EFDD opposes fundamentally the allocation of €1.5 billion via the Flexibility Instrument for migration management, viewing it as a policy failure that exacerbates security risks and Schengen instability while neglecting vulnerable refugees in third countries.  
EFDD rejects the budget’s structural contradictions, particularly the €140 million payment reduction and agency staffing contortions (e.g., ACER +5 posts, Parliament -9 posts), which perpetuate institutional inefficiencies instead of rationalizing priorities.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s approach to youth unemployment through programs like COSME and Erasmus+, arguing uncontrolled immigration undermines job accessibility for EU citizens without addressing labor market root causes.  
EFDD highlights the budget’s failure to correct systemic overreach, citing the €460.1 million payment appropriation cuts as insufficient to align with national sovereignty principles or address long-term fiscal imbalances.  
EFDD disputes the institutional compromises on Horizon 2020 and pilot project funding, asserting they entangle EU competencies in areas better managed at member-state level.

ENF rejects the 2016 budget's €710 million immigration provisions as dangerously insufficient to secure borders, entirely opposeing with ENF's demand for national sovereignty over frontier protection.  
ENF opposes all funding to Turkey as sponsorship of terrorism, citing the issue's €24 million Global Europe commitments as incompatible with European security interests.  
ENF condemns agricultural crisis allocations as hypocritical subsidies compensating for EU-caused trade embargoes, inconsistent with ENF's anti-sanctions stance toward Russia.  
The issue's Security and Citizenship expenditures fail to address ENF's core principle that "Islamist-friendly" external actors like Turkey threaten continental stability.  
ENF totally challenges Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings enabling unchecked agency expansions (+26 posts total), which entrench Brussels bureaucracy against national autonomy.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s increases to Horizon 2020, COSME, and Erasmus+ funding, aligning perfectly with their commitment to advancing research, entrepreneurship, and cross-border educational opportunities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the strengthened transparency measures, particularly the adoption of their amendment to disclose expenditure allowances, effectively advancing institutional accountability as a core democratic principle.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the mobilization of flexibility funds for refugee programs and global citizenship priorities, reflecting their humanitarian focus while proposing enhanced allocations to address climate migration dimensions.  
GREEN_EFA acknowledges progress on payment backlog commitments but urges reallocating resources from ITER to EU security and crisis-response mechanisms as a strategic enhancement to address terrorism and displacement challenges.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need to accelerate reforms toward genuine EU "own resources" and a budget prioritizing collective action over national redistributions, framing this issue as a step toward deeper financial autonomy.

ALDE fully supports the 2016 budget’s prioritization of migration response and SME funding through the Flexibility Instrument, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to crisis resilience and economic innovation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the reversal of Council cuts to Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+, recognizing these enhancements as critical to advancing ALDE’s research and youth mobility agendas.  
ALDE applauds the retention of the Youth Employment Initiative, which directly reflects ALDE’s manifesto focus on combating EU-wide unemployment through targeted fiscal measures.  
ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on reducing payment backlogs, a strategic alignment with ALDE’s long-standing advocacy for budgetary accountability and operational efficiency.  
ALDE commends the integration of performance-based budgeting principles, a cornerstone of ALDE’s fiscal policy vision to prevent arbitrary financial cuts in Member States.

SD entirely promotes the mobilization of €1.5 billion via the Flexibility Instrument for migration and security crises, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to solidarity-driven fiscal responses to extraordinary challenges.  
SD perfectly aligns with the prioritization of Horizon 2020, COSME, and Erasmus+ funding increases, advancing SD’s manifesto goals for innovation, SME growth, and youth opportunity.  
SD applauds the budgetary consensus on agricultural support and refugee crisis allocations, reflecting SD’s unwavering advocacy for vulnerable sectors and humanitarian imperatives.  
SD recognizes the institutional staffing adjustments as a balanced approach to administrative efficiency, effectively advancing SD’s principles of judicious resource allocation without compromising operational capacity.  
SD entirely promotes the cross-institutional collaboration demonstrated in negotiations, exemplifying SD’s longstanding commitment to resolving structural budget limitations through dialogue over austerity.

ECR partly upholds the migration crisis allocations but demands binding amendments requiring member state compliance with integrated border control strategies, inconsistent with the issue's open-ended funding approach.  
ECR requests structural revision of cohesion policy mechanisms to introduce performance-based funding clawbacks where competitiveness targets remain unmet after three years.  
ECR fully opposes the €1.5 billion Flexibility Instrument activation for Heading 3 without explicit guarantees against future raids on agricultural or cohesion budgets.  
ECR requires amendment of Horizon 2020 payment schedules to prioritize SME innovation grants over institutional research partnerships.  
ECR rejects the crisis-response paradigm for security funding, advocating instead for permanent intelligence-sharing infrastructure investments rather than temporary budget increases.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2016 budget's failure to address structural constraints of the Multiannual Financial Framework, which perpetuates inadequate funding for youth employment initiatives and social priorities.  
GUE_NGL opposes the unresolved payment appropriations crisis, noting it directly contradicts demands for sustainable fiscal planning aligned with climate and solidarity agendas.  
GUE_NGL condemns cuts to plant/animal pest control budgets (-€11 million) as fundamentally inconsistent with ecological protection principles amid climate-driven epidemiological risks.  
GUE_NGL disputes the symbolic Erasmus+ funding increase, emphasizing its negligible impact compared to systemic underinvestment in social programs.  
GUE_NGL opposes immigration budget allocations that prioritize punitive measures over development aid, exacerbating humanitarian crises rather than resolving them.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the definitive adoption of the EU’s 2016 general budget, setting commitment appropriations at €155,004.2 million (leaving a €2,331.4 million margin below the Multiannual Financial Framework ceiling) and payment appropriations at €143,885.3 million. It mobilized the Flexibility Instrument for €1,506 million (Heading 3: Security and Citizenship) and €24 million (Heading 4: Global Europe) in commitments, with related 2016 payments estimated at €832.8 million. For 2015, Draft Amending Budget 8/2015 was approved, including adjustments to agency staffing and funding: increases for the European Chemicals Agency (-€1.35 million despite +3 posts), European Aviation Safety Agency (+6 posts), European Medicines Agency (+3 posts), ACER (+5 posts, +€325,000), FRA (+2 posts, +€130,000), Eurojust (+2 posts, +€130,000), and EBA (+€928,000), alongside reductions for eu-LISA (-€260,000). Commitments for Horizon 2020, COSME, and Erasmus+ were increased, while institutional adjustments included a 9-post reduction for Parliament and +7 posts (+€300,000) for the Court of Justice. Payment appropriations were adjusted via three mechanisms: a €140 million decrease for non-differentiated expenditures, a €29.5 million increase for pilot/preparatory projects, and a €460.1 million reduction in other payments. The resolution confirmed joint institutional statements and instructed the publication and communication of the adopted budget.

title: 2017 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: The European Union faced 2016 migration pressures, security challenges, and post-financial crisis economic recovery needs requiring budgetary adjustments under the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss the 2017 general budget's alignment with priorities including migration management, security reinforcement, youth employment, and growth initiatives within existing fiscal parameters.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the budget's focus on growth and job creation through reinforced innovation funding and SME support programs like COSME.  
EPP approves the strategic allocation of €530 million for security agencies Europol and Eurojust, aligning with their priority of combating cross-border threats.  
EPP endorses maintaining strict MFF discipline while utilizing flexibility mechanisms to address migration challenges and youth unemployment.  
EPP proposes enhancing member state accountability by linking future fund disbursements to compliance with refugee relocation agreements.  
EPP applauds the €500 million Youth Employment Initiative increase as directly advancing their manifesto commitment to combat youth unemployment.

EFDD totally condemns the 2017 budget's reliance on the Flexibility Instrument and Contingency Margin mechanisms, viewing them as fiscal sleight-of-hand to bypass spending limits while extracting €1.1 billion from taxpayers.  
EFDD rejects the inclusion of Draft Amending Budget 5/2016 forcing UK contributions of €700 million as unacceptable given the Brexit referendum mandate to cease EU payments.  
EFDD condemns the 3.3% salary increase for EU officials and €13.4 million administrative expenditure adjustments as institutional profligacy contradicting austerity demands.  
EFDD disputes the claimed "victimless" nature of agricultural cuts while maintaining inflated budgets for EUROPOL (€675,000 staff expansion) and EASO (€3 million increase).  
EFDD highlights the issue's failure to address Court of Auditors' systemic mismanagement findings, particularly regarding €981.1 million in legacy payment appropriations from prior budgets.

ENF fully challenges with the 10% budget increase for Palestinian aid (€300 million annually), denouncing it as direct support for entities engaging in anti-Semitic violence  
ENF rejects the €6 billion allocation to Turkey as capitulation to "Islamist blackmail" under Erdogan's regime, contrary to European security interests  
ENF opposes the €177 million expenditure for migrant maintenance in Italy, declaring it prioritizes "fake refugees" over unemployed EU citizens  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to address youth unemployment exceeding 50% in Southern Europe while funding "failed economic policies"  
ENF highlights the budget's moral bankruptcy through €1.91 billion contingency margins that perpetuate uncontrolled spending on "EU propaganda projects"

GREEN_EFA firmly disputes the 2017 budget's erosion of climate action funding, as the €325 million agricultural cut and token Horizon 2020 allocations violate their decarbonization mandates.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the Youth Employment Initiative's €500 million allocation as structurally inadequate, failing to meet the €1.5 billion annual threshold required for meaningful social cohesion.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the abolished Solidarity Fund reserve, which dismantles critical crisis-response capacities central to their regional equity principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the Council-driven "resources available" logic, which subordinates parliamentary authority and long-term EU sustainability goals to short-term fiscal constraints.  
GREEN_EFA highlights institutional credibility damage from unresolved Code of Conduct violations, directly contradicting their transparency advocacy in budgetary governance.

ALDE absolutely upholds the 2017 EU budget issue, highlighting its alignment with priorities such as youth mobility, SME support through COSME, and Horizon 2020 research funding.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the budget’s unprecedented efforts to address the migration crisis and enhance internal security, reflecting their commitment to EU solidarity and protection.  
ALDE applauds the successful mobilization of trust-building measures with the Commission, as exemplified by Vice-President Georgieva’s collaborative approach, ensuring parliamentary involvement in budgetary processes.  
ALDE recognizes the issue’s support for agricultural sectors affected by external embargoes, particularly dairy producers, as a critical component of EU economic resilience.  
ALDE commends the Conciliation Committee’s tenacity in achieving a balanced budget that maintains fiscal responsibility while addressing urgent priorities, reinforcing the efficacy of interinstitutional cooperation.

SD strongly endorses the increased funding for the Youth Employment Initiative (€500 million), recognizing its vital role in combating youth unemployment as a core social democratic priority.  
SD approves the mobilization of flexibility instruments (€1.44 billion Global Margin for Competitiveness, €1.91 billion Contingency Margin) as strategically aligning with SD's emphasis on adaptable crisis response mechanisms.  
SD endorses the €200 million reinforcement for Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programs, affirming their critical importance in advancing research-based growth strategies central to SD's agenda.  
SD proposes enhancing parliamentary oversight in future MFF revisions to institutionalize budgetary flexibility while maintaining current agreement parameters.  
SD commends the €5.9 billion allocation for migration management and security as responsive to SD's demands for solidarity-based solutions to humanitarian challenges.

ECR fully disputes the 2017 budget's allocation of 72% to agriculture and cohesion policies, which perpetuates inefficient spending without demonstrating EU-added value.  
ECR rejects the €23 billion gap between commitments and payments as fiscally irresponsible, foreseeing future unpaid bills and budgetary instability.  
ECR opposes the failure to reallocate Turkey accession funds despite Parliament's issue to suspend negotiations, highlighting a contradiction in fiscal priorities.  
ECR criticizes the austerity-driven approach for migration crises, noting grossly inadequate funding (€115 million for asylum) to support frontline states like Greece.  
ECR disputes the inclusion of the Youth Employment Initiative, deeming it ineffective compared to education reform and economic growth strategies.

GUE_NGL completely opposes the 2017 budget for institutionalizing austerity through €325 million cuts to agricultural expenditure and reduced social cohesion funding, directly contradicting their commitment to equitable rural support.  
GUE_NGL rejects the prioritization of security spending (e.g., doubled internal security funds) over climate action and public services, which overlooks existential crises like poverty affecting 24% of Europeans.  
GUE_NGL condemns the abolition of the Solidarity Fund reserve and Interrail tokenism as failures to address youth unemployment’s democratic erosion, inconsistent with demands for radical employment initiatives.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s structural betrayal of SMEs and workers through payment appropriation limits (50% for pilot projects), exacerbating precarity instead of fostering economic justice.  
GUE_NGL asserts the budget’s reliance on Trust Funds and contingency margins entrenches neoliberal governance, incompatible with their vision of democratically accountable fiscal policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the 2017 EU budget with commitment appropriations set at €157.86 billion, leaving a €1.1 billion margin below the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) ceilings, and payment appropriations at €134.49 billion. Key allocations included mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument (€530 million for Security and Citizenship), the Global Margin (€1.44 billion for Competitiveness), and the Contingency Margin (€1.91 billion for headings 3 and 4, offset by reductions in other headings). Payment appropriations linked to prior Flexibility Instrument mobilizations (2014-2016) totaled €981.1 million. For 2016, amendments included accepting Draft Amending Budgets 4/2016 (Contingency Margin), 5/2016, and 6/2016 (Solidarity Fund), alongside agency adjustments: EUROPOL and EUROJUST each received 10 additional posts (€675,000), the EBA faced a €500,000 reduction, EASO gained €3 million, and EMA was cut by €8.35 million. Agricultural expenditure was reduced by €325 million, administrative expenditure adjusted by €13.4 million, and payment rules for pilot projects set at 50% of commitments. The Solidarity Fund reserve was abolished, and further reductions required enhanced reporting on Trust Funds, annual working documents, and parliamentary involvement in budgetary measures.

title: 2018 budgetary procedure: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: The European Union's 2018 budgetary procedure followed established multiannual financial framework (2014-2020) protocols, with negotiations between the Commission, Council, and Parliament to reconcile competing priorities under constrained fiscal conditions. The Parliament will discuss finalizing annual expenditure allocations across policy areas including migration management, security cooperation, economic competitiveness, and youth employment initiatives within institutional budget ceilings.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the increased allocation of €350 million for youth employment initiatives, aligning with its priority to combat EU-wide youth unemployment through concrete workforce development programs.  
EPP approves the reversal of Council cuts to Horizon 2020 and COSME funding, emphasizing their critical role in maintaining Europe’s scientific competitiveness and SME growth as outlined in the issue’s Heading 1a commitments.  
EPP endorses the €2 billion allocation for cross-border infrastructure projects like Rail Baltic, which directly advances territorial cohesion and single-market connectivity under Heading 1b priorities.  
EPP proposes reinforcing human rights conditionality mechanisms for external funding, building on the €105 million reduction to Turkey, to systematically link budget access to democratic governance benchmarks.  
EPP applauds the €1.1 million allocation for countering disinformation campaigns as a vital first step in safeguarding EU democratic processes, consistent with its security-focused agenda in Heading 3.

EFDD firmly doubts the 2018 EU budget's assumption of continued UK financial contributions post-Brexit, which disregards the democratic mandate of the 2016 referendum.  
EFDD rejects the inclusion of any "divorce bill" payments from the UK as legally unfounded and contrary to Article 50's stipulation that treaties cease upon withdrawal.  
EFDD condemns the budget's failure to implement necessary spending reductions despite the impending loss of the UK's 16% contribution to EU finances.  
EFDD challenges the allocation of funds for EU propaganda projects like the "House of History" while maintaining excessive budgetary demands on member states.  
EFDD disputes the validity of continued UK payments into EU programs after 2018 without reciprocal concessions or tangible benefits in ongoing Brexit negotiations.

ENF rejects the 2018 budget's expansion as a parasitic growth threatening European sovereignty, directly contradicting ENF's principle of fiscal restraint and national control over taxation.  
ENF opposes fundamentally the allocation of €131 million to Turkey and Balkan accession funds, which violates ENF's stance against rewarding states undermining EU values or public opposition to enlargement.  
ENF condemns the proposed EU propaganda budget as ideological overreach, challenging ENF's commitment to free speech by allowing unaccountable "truth" arbiters.  
ENF rejects the prioritization of migration management funds over youth and research programs, conflicting with ENF's manifesto to address core European demographic crises.  
ENF opposes the exploitation of "flexibility instruments" to bypass spending limits, cementing ENF's argument that EU institutions deliberately evade fiscal accountability frameworks.

GREEN_EFA rejects the 2018 budget's allocation of €837.2 million through the Flexibility Instrument for Security and Citizenship, totally challengeing with their principle of prioritizing social cohesion over militarization.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the deferred Contingency Margin adjustments as structurally inadequate, failing to address systemic underfunding of climate transition programs in Heading 1a and 1b.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Court of Auditors' €1 million transfer for celebratory events, highlighting a pattern of fiscal irresponsibility inconsistent with their manifesto demand for austerity in administrative spending.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding environmental safeguards in new pilot projects, which remain capped at 50% commitments without sustainability criteria.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the agricultural expenditure reductions as undermining rural green initiatives, directly contradicting their agricultural biodiversity protection agenda.

ALDE strongly advocates the 2018 budget’s increased funding for research, youth employment initiatives, and SME competitiveness, aligning with their priorities for economic growth and job creation.  
ALDE approves the €105 million reduction in Turkey’s pre-accession funds, reinforcing the EU’s commitment to democratic values and opposition to authoritarian governance.  
ALDE applauds the bolstered resources for Europol, Eurojust, and the Stratcom program, recognizing their critical role in countering terrorism and foreign disinformation campaigns.  
ALDE endorses the climate action allocations while proposing enhanced monitoring to ensure future budgets meet the 20% spending target mandated by the Paris Agreement.  
ALDE advocates for reforming the Multiannual Financial Framework to enable greater flexibility in reallocating funds between priorities and simplifying contingency instrument activation.

SD entirely againsts the 2018 budget issue for institutionalizing austerity in agricultural policy through a €229.9 million cut, directly contradicting SD's commitment to food sovereignty and rural development.  
SD rejects the Council's exclusive focus on financial margins over political priorities, particularly the failure to adequately fund migration management systems and refugee integration programs demanded by citizens.  
The proposal overlooks SD's core principle of fiscal justice by allowing opaque budget maneuvers like deferring €252 million in administrative offsets to 2020 rather than addressing tax avoidance through binding rules.  
SD condemns the negotiation process that forced last-minute compromises on youth employment initiatives like Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020, reducing their transformative potential through capped implementation funds.  
This budget structurally conflicts with SD's vision of EU solidarity by maintaining disproportionate cohesion policy cuts for Central/Eastern Europe while protecting discretionary Council spending privileges.

ECR rejects the 2018 budget's allocation of over 70% to agriculture and cohesion policies (Headings 1a, 1b), firmly disputeing with ECR's demand for fiscal prioritization of research, border security, and migration management.  
ECR opposes the €144.7 billion payment appropriations as insufficient to prevent recurring backlog crises, citing unresolved 2012–2014 payment delays and inadequate alignment with Multiannual Financial Framework implementation urgency.  
ECR condemns funding to Turkey and Albania under Security and Citizenship (Heading 3), declaring it inconsistent with EU values due to territorial violations against Greece and Cyprus, and human rights abuses against Greek minorities.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of ECR's fiscal responsibility principles by perpetuating bureaucratic inefficiencies evidenced by €10 billion unspent in 2017, instead of restructuring subsidy models to phase out long-term dependencies.  
ECR disputes the Contingency Margin adjustments (Heading 5) as insufficiently transformative, maintaining systemic overcommitment to administrative expenditures rather than redirecting resources to innovation-driven growth.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2018 budget’s prioritization of security and defense over migration and asylum, which directly contradicts their commitment to solidarity and human rights by reallocating €837.2 million via the Flexibility Instrument to Heading 3.  
GUE_NGL opposes the budget’s failure to address inflationary pressures, as the 1.4% increase in real terms falls below the 1.7% CPI rise, entrenching austerity measures inconsistent with social equity principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the allocation of €1.1 billion from the Global Margin to fossil fuel infrastructure in Headings 1a and 1b, which totally condemns with their mandate for a sustainable energy transition.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s disregard for environmental needs by deferring €252 million in contingency funds to 2020, delaying critical green investments outlined in their manifesto.  
GUE_NGL challenges the €229.9 million cut to agricultural expenditure, a reduction antithetical to their advocacy for sustainable food systems and rural development.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of the EU’s 2018 general budget, setting commitment appropriations at €160.1 billion (with a €1.6 billion margin below the Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings) and payment appropriations at €144.7 billion. It mobilized the Flexibility Instrument for €837.2 million under Security and Citizenship (Heading 3) and allocated €1.1 billion from the Global Margin to Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs (Heading 1a) and Economic, Social, and Territorial Cohesion (Heading 1b). Adjustments to the Contingency Margin reduced offsetting in Administration (Heading 5) from €570 million to €318 million in 2018, with €252 million deferred to 2020. Payment appropriations linked to the Flexibility Instrument across 2014–2018 were estimated at €678.3 million. For 2017, agricultural expenditure was reduced by €229.9 million, resulting in a net decrease of €255.3 million, while payment appropriations for new pilot projects and preparatory actions were capped at 50% of commitments (or lower if proposed), adding €50 million. The resolution approved new budget lines, pilot actions, and a dedicated European External Action Service item, aligning with Commission proposals and amendments.

title: 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and own resources: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework and own resources
background: The European Commission's May 2018 proposal for the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework addressed post-Brexit budget adjustments and new EU priorities amid existing commitments. With the UK's withdrawal creating funding gaps and evolving challenges in security, migration, and climate action, the Parliament will discuss the seven-year budget structure and revenue sources.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves maintaining cohesion policy funding at 2014-2020 real-term levels, aligning with the issue's emphasis on territorial solidarity and rejecting disproportionate cuts to the Cohesion Fund.  
EPP fully advocates tripling Erasmus+ funding as critical for youth development, reflecting their manifesto priority of investing in Europe's future generations.
