GUE_NGL welcomes transparency frameworks as foundational but urges stricter anti-tax-haven clauses to align the regulation with their manifesto commitments to fiscal justice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined its position on the EU’s budgetary framework and own resources system, emphasizing adherence to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020 on budgetary discipline, cooperation, and new own resources. It approved the Council’s draft decision (12771/2020) on the EU’s own resources system as amended, while urging the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text and to re-consult Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. The resolution reiterated longstanding priorities from previous resolutions, including reforms to the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the need for a robust recovery plan, aligning with Treaty provisions (TFEU Article 322(2) and Euratom Article 106a). It stressed the importance of transparency and institutional balance in budgetary negotiations, instructing its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission. The amendment to Article 1(8) of the draft regulation highlighted specific adjustments to the own resources mechanism, though detailed content was not specified in the resolution text.

title: Guidelines for the 2022 Budget - Section III: REPORT on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2022 budget, Section III – Commission | A9-0046/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic caused severe economic contraction, rising unemployment, and strained health systems across the EU, exacerbating existing challenges like climate targets under the Paris Agreement, digital infrastructure gaps, and regional disparities. The Parliament will discuss 2022 budget priorities to address recovery, green and digital transitions, health resilience, and cohesion.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the budget's focus on effective implementation mechanisms, particularly the utilization of penalty-derived funds to reinforce core EU policies, aligning with EPP's commitment to fiscal responsibility and Recovery Fund optimization.  
EPP proposes enhancing rule of law conditionality by explicitly extending scrutiny to third-country beneficiaries like Turkey, ensuring EU funds exclusively support partners adhering to democratic values.  
EPP approves the human-centric allocation model for SMEs and citizens, while recommending amendments to include targeted support for Greek Cypriot refugees through dedicated budgetary lines.  
EPP endorses the issue’s cohesion priorities and urges accelerated adoption of the European Student Card and Disability Card frameworks to operationalize inclusive recovery measures.  
EPP applauds the linkage between budget disbursements and rule of law compliance, advocating stricter enforcement protocols for non-EU recipients to uphold EPP’s governance principles.

SD perfectly aligns with the call for Schengen expansion to Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia, emphasizing this as critical to fostering EU solidarity and mobility in line with SD’s cohesion policy advocacy.  
SD fully accepts the emphasis on accelerating EU4Health investments, proposing enhanced vaccine production transparency under HERA to address disparities in vaccination rates while upholding medical sovereignty commitments.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for gender-responsive budgeting and 10% RRF allocations to education, urging explicit earmarking for digital upskilling programs to advance SD’s youth employment priorities.  
SD fully accepts strict climate tracking methodologies, advocating for real-time public dashboards to ensure the 30% MFF climate allocation meets SD’s green transition benchmarks.

RENEW strongly upholds the prioritization of SMEs through enhanced Single Market Programme funding, aligning perfectly with RENEW's longstanding commitment to fostering innovation-driven economic resilience.  
RENEW applauds the 30% climate allocation and biodiversity targets, which effectively advance RENEW's priority of embedding sustainability across all EU policy frameworks.  
RENEW approves the emphasis on EU4Health and cancer research, recognizing this as a critical step toward addressing systemic healthcare gaps highlighted during the pandemic.  
RENEW proposes strengthening the issue’s climate tracking methodologies by mandating real-time public dashboards to enhance accountability without opposing the targets.  
RENEW strongly upholds dedicating 10% of RRF funds to education and youth employment, a measure that aligns with RENEW’s manifesto goals for inclusive, future-proof growth.

GREEN_EFA absolutely advocates the issue's climate prioritization, perfectly aligning with their mandate to channel 30% of MFF funds toward decarbonization and green industrial innovation as critical for Paris Agreement compliance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the gender-responsive budgeting provisions, emphasizing their structural requirement for equitable recovery and parity-driven investment frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely advocates tripling Erasmus+ funding and dedicating RRF education allocations, recognizing these as foundational to youth empowerment and intergenerational equity.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the conditional Frontex funding as fully congruent with their demand for rigorous human rights oversight and rejection of border agency impunity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s integration of Creative Europe and Horizon Europe, vital for sustaining cultural resilience alongside green-digital research ecosystems.

ECR rejects the accelerated implementation of the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) as outlined in the climate action provisions, citing disproportionate financial burdens on Eastern European member states without adequate impact assessments.  
ECR opposes the increased funding for the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), arguing that it duplicates existing frameworks like OLAF and national prosecutors, thereby creating bureaucratic redundancy.  
ECR completely disputes with the issue’s approach to centralized climate legislation, asserting that it infringes on national competencies and violates subsidiarity principles by overriding member states’ authority in unceded policy areas.  
ECR criticizes the issue’s climate expenditure targets (30% MFF allocation) as neglecting the socio-economic realities of less affluent EU countries, which face severe costs in decarbonization efforts.  
ECR challenges the rule of law conditionality mechanisms tied to budget allocations, viewing them as instruments that undermine national sovereignty and contradict the 2021 conclusions on balanced application criteria.

ID rejects the issue's emphasis on expanded funding mechanisms as totally rejecting with ID's principle of fiscal restraint, citing unresolved citizen distrust in EU financial management.  
ID opposes the climate allocation quotas (30% MFF) as emblematic of empty "green transition" rhetoric that neglects SME operational realities across member states.  
The proposal's Great Reset-aligned societal restructuring totally rejects with ID's demand for political honesty over ideological buzzwords like "inclusive recovery."  
ID condemns the lack of accountability safeguards in Frontex funding increases as perpetuating the EU's pattern of creating problems rather than solving them.  
The issue's focus on new own resources (digital levy, carbon tax) overlooks critical ID warnings about compounding economic burdens during ongoing inflation crises.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to mandate full taxation of internet giants as a sustainable revenue source for public health and social investments.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the increased Frontex funding provisions, which contradict their anti-militarist border policy principles.  
This proposal firmly doubts with GUE_NGL's demand to reallocate 100% of unspent MFF funds and fines to combat pandemic-induced inequalities.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of wealth redistribution by maintaining structural reliance on regressive financial instruments rather than binding corporate contributions.  
GUE_NGL condemns the insufficient binding targets for social spending in education and healthcare compared to the scale of youth unemployment and public health crises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative of aligning the 2022 EU budget with recovery from the COVID-19 crisis, emphasizing support for SMEs (constituting 99% of EU businesses and 75% of jobs) through enhanced funding via the Single Market Programme, InvestEU, and Horizon Europe to drive innovation, digital skills, and green transitions. It stressed the need to allocate 30% of the MFF and recovery funds to climate action, with 7.5% of annual spending for biodiversity by 2024 and 10% by 2026, while prioritizing cohesion policy to reduce regional disparities and foster job creation. The resolution highlighted the EU4Health programme as the bloc’s largest health initiative, urging investments in vaccine production, HERA, and cancer research (noting 2.7 million cancer diagnoses and 1.3 million deaths in 2020), alongside strengthening EMA and ECDC. It called for inclusive recovery measures, including boosting Erasmus+, dedicating 10% of RRF funds to education, addressing youth unemployment, and implementing gender-responsive budgeting. The Parliament emphasized expanding Schengen to Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia, increasing Frontex funding with accountability, and upholding rule of law via the EPPO. It demanded accelerated MFF implementation, including EURI commitments (60% by 2022) and new own resources (carbon border tax, digital levy) by July 2022, while addressing delays in programme rollouts and ensuring adequate payments to avoid fiscal crises. Tourism, cultural sectors, and defense innovation were flagged for targeted support, alongside migration management and NDICI funding for external challenges. The resolution underscored strict monitoring of climate and digital targets, including 20% RRF allocations for digital transition, and robust tracking methodologies for budgetary transparency.

title: Guidelines for the 2023 budget – Section III: REPORT on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2023 budget, Section III – Commission | A9-0062/2022 | European Parliament

The Parliament will discuss 2023 EU budget priorities addressing pandemic recovery, green/digital transitions, health system resilience, and geopolitical stability within existing financial frameworks.

EPP proposes enhancing energy price control mechanisms by prioritizing the Greek Prime Minister’s wholesale gas cap proposal as a crisis response measure, while maintaining full alignment with green transition goals.  
EPP applauds the issue’s integration of pandemic recovery with digital/green investments, matching José Manuel Fernandes’ emphasis on long-term union through health, energy, and digital sovereignty initiatives.

GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the issue's integration of climate and biodiversity protection across all budgetary lines, particularly through strengthened LIFE Programme funding and Just Transition Mechanism allocations to phase out fossil fuel dependencies.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the insistence on strict rule of law conditionality to safeguard EU funds, emphasizing the critical need for independent judiciaries as exemplified in debates about Poland’s constitutional governance.  
GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the prioritization of gender mainstreaming through dedicated resources for the Daphne strand and systematic tracking of gender-related expenditures, advancing intersectional equality frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the unequivocal condemnation of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine and the allocation of urgent humanitarian aid, reflecting their commitment to European solidarity and democratic sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA entirely promotes enhanced climate expenditure verification methodologies and biodiversity safeguards, ensuring alignment with IPCC-recommended 1.5°C pathways across all EU spending instruments.

ECR opposes gender-based budget allocations and references to reproductive rights, deeming them secondary to urgent security and refugee crisis expenditures.  
ECR fully againsts with claims of systemic EU fund misuse in Poland, demanding concrete evidence over political accusations.  
ECR condemns the issue’s delayed recognition of Ukraine war impacts, insisting on immediate budgetary flexibility for refugee integration costs in frontline states like Poland.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of energy price inflation and agricultural disruptions caused by Russian aggression, requiring dedicated crisis-response funding streams.

ID rejects the issue's prioritization of the European Green Deal, arguing that energy independence and strategic food sovereignty must take precedence over climate neutrality targets, which neglect immediate economic crises impacting citizens and SMEs.  
ID opposes the expansion of NextGenerationEU debt instruments, warning that uncertain repayment timelines and potential member state liabilities contradict fiscal responsibility principles essential during inflationary pressures.  
ID entirely doubts with the issue's support for Western Balkans enlargement, asserting that premature integration without meeting EU standards risks budgetary misallocation and undermines cohesion policy objectives.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as family values and subsidiarity, failing to address societal foundations while excessively focusing on gender-related expenditures and centralized health authority structures.  
ID condemns the issue's global "Europe in the World" programming, demanding reallocation of external neighborhood funds to domestic crisis response as a core EU mandate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for the 2023 EU budget to prioritize economic recovery, resilience, and strategic investments amid challenges such as the COVID-19 pandemic, energy crises, and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. It emphasized aligning spending with the European Green Deal to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, including increased funding for LIFE, the Just Transition Mechanism, and green infrastructure under the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF). The digital transition was highlighted as critical, with calls to bolster Horizon Europe, Digital Europe, and CEF-Digital to enhance competitiveness, cybersecurity, and AI development. The resolution stressed the importance of cohesion policy, allocating 2% of Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) funds to cultural sectors, 10% to education, and 5% of European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) resources to the European Child Guarantee. Health priorities included reinforcing EU4Health, addressing HERA’s funding gaps, and supporting the Beating Cancer Plan. Support for SMEs, tourism, and cultural sectors impacted by the pandemic was urged, alongside demands for fresh resources for initiatives like the New European Bauhaus. The Parliament insisted on strict application of the rule of law conditionality mechanism (Regulation 2020/2092) to protect EU funds, adequate funding for the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), and increased resources for the Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values programme. Youth-focused measures, including Erasmus+ expansion and addressing pandemic-related educational gaps, were prioritized. The resolution condemned Russia’s aggression against Ukraine, demanding urgent humanitarian aid, support for refugees, and enhanced defense funding via the European Defence Fund. It called for increased migration and asylum funding, emphasizing solidarity among Member States. To finance these priorities, the Parliament urged swift adoption of new own resources, including a carbon border adjustment mechanism and emissions trading revenues, while opposing cuts to existing programmes. Gender equality measures, such as funding the Daphne strand to combat gender-based violence and tracking gender-related expenditures, were emphasized. Lastly, the resolution highlighted the need for sufficient payment appropriations to avoid payment backlogs, improved climate and biodiversity expenditure tracking, and adequate staffing for EU agencies to fulfill their mandates.

title: European Parliament resolution on the new multiannual financial framework, own resources and the recovery plan: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the new multiannual financial framework, own resources and the recovery plan | B9-0158/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic severely strained EU member states’ welfare systems, deepened socio-economic inequalities, and disrupted economic activity, with a projected 7.4% GDP contraction. Pre-existing debates on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and EU commitments to climate neutrality, digitalization, and cohesion required reassessment amid crisis conditions. The Parliament will discuss integrating recovery measures into the MFF while balancing long-term strategic priorities and fiscal sustainability.

EPP strongly sanctions conditionality linking funds to climate neutrality and rule of law compliance, emphasizing this aligns perfectly with their governance principles while protecting EU financial interests.

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the rejection of intergovernmental approaches, demanding Parliament's oversight role as essential to prevent fragmented national egoism in crisis management.  
GREEN_EFA completely sanctions prioritizing green/digital transitions and health system resilience, seeing this as the operationalization of their "Civilization Shift" agenda outlined in the 2019 European elections.

ECR advises maintaining cohesion policy allocations at current levels to preserve regional development priorities, proposing budget reallocations rather than cuts to existing programs.  
ECR expresses concern about Green Deal implementation timelines conflicting with industrial competitiveness, recommending phased carbon targets in Annex III to prevent job losses.  
ECR endorses strict anti-tax fraud measures aligned with national enforcement frameworks but opposes centralized EU tax authorities as proposed in Section 8(c).  
ECR calls for binding amendments to prioritize single market protections against foreign takeovers through enhanced state aid flexibility in Chapter 4.

ID rejects fundamentally the proposed €2 trillion Recovery and Transformation Fund as an unacceptable expansion of EU debt mechanisms that would impose permanent fiscal burdens on member states through new digital and financial transaction taxes.  
ID opposes the issue's climate neutrality conditionality as ideological overreach, citing evidence from reduced emissions during lockdowns that disproves the Green Deal's scientific basis while ignoring urgent family economic needs.  
ID condemns the issue's reliance on EU-guaranteed bonds as a direct path to fiscal colonialism, forcing indebted nations like Italy into austerity traps disguised as solidarity through repayment obligations.  
ID rejects the undemocratic centralization of oversight powers in EU institutions, demanding absolute national control over strategic sectors and veto rights against Chinese economic infiltration as outlined in Article 3.  
ID opposes the carbon border adjustment mechanism as a disguised protectionist tool that would escalate trade tensions with China while failing to address Europe's critical dependency on foreign medical supplies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe socio-economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, including a projected 7.4% contraction in EU GDP, increased inequalities, unemployment, and strain on welfare systems, while emphasizing the need for a robust, equitable recovery strategy anchored in the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2021-2027. It demanded that the revised MFF integrate a €2 trillion Recovery and Transformation Fund financed through EU-guaranteed long-term bonds, prioritizing grants, direct investments, and equity to support SMEs, green and digital transitions, health systems, and strategic industrial sovereignty, while ensuring alignment with the European Green Deal, UN Sustainable Development Goals, and social rights. The resolution stressed that recovery efforts must not compromise existing EU programs or long-term priorities, insisting on new own resources—such as digital taxes, carbon border adjustments, and financial transaction taxes—to fund the MFF and avoid over-reliance on member states’ GNI contributions. It warned against intergovernmental approaches, demanding Parliament’s central role in oversight and rejecting any MFF proposal lacking democratic accountability or sufficient ambition. Additionally, the Parliament called for strict conditionality linking funds to climate neutrality, tax compliance, and rule of law, while advocating international solidarity and a standalone EU health program to bolster crisis resilience.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over delays in adopting the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and Own Resources system, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, which hindered the 2021 budget process. It emphasized prioritizing recovery efforts through the EU Recovery Plan and Next Generation EU (NGEU), focusing on the European Green Deal, digital transformation, and socioeconomic convergence. The resolution set ambitious climate and biodiversity targets, demanding at least 30% climate mainstreaming and 10% biodiversity spending in 2021, with strict eligibility criteria aligned with the EU Taxonomy Regulation to exclude fossil fuel subsidies. Key flagship programs, including Horizon Europe (€120 billion over 2021-2027), Erasmus+ (tripled funding), EU4Health, and the Just Transition Fund, were reinforced, with total commitment appropriations for the 2021 budget raised to €181.76 billion, an increase of €15.02 billion over the Commission’s draft. Specific allocations included €1 billion for the European Child Guarantee, €500 million for the Just Transition Fund, and €237 million for the LIFE program. The Parliament also prioritized support for COVID-19-affected sectors like tourism, culture, and SMEs, while demanding transparency in budget lines and enhanced resources for agencies such as Frontex, ECDC, and EMA. It rejected Council cuts to critical areas, insisted on gender mainstreaming, and called for a dedicated Search and Rescue Fund in the Mediterranean. The resolution stressed the need for sufficient payment appropriations to address outstanding commitments and ensure liquidity, while opposing rule of law deficiencies affecting EU budget integrity. External action funding was bolstered, with NDICI allocations aligned with Parliament’s priorities, and humanitarian aid was increased to address global challenges worsened by the pandemic.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Council’s proposed cuts of €1.51 billion to the 2020 EU budget, which it deemed contradictory to EU priorities, and restored funding to the Commission’s original draft levels. Emphasizing climate action, the resolution allocated over €2 billion to reinforce climate-related expenditure across programs, targeting a 20% climate spending goal for 2014-2020, with 21% of the proposed 2020 commitments already climate-related. It highlighted the need for €175–290 billion annually to meet climate targets and reinforced Horizon 2020 by €737.8 million, including €280.7 million from de-commitments for climate research. Youth initiatives were prioritized, with a €363.3 million increase for the Youth Employment Initiative and a €123.4 million boost for Erasmus+ to expand participation. The resolution strengthened cohesion policies (€373.3 million), biodiversity protection via LIFE+ (€233 million), and security/migration programs, rejecting Council cuts to AMIF and ISF. External action funding rose by €257.2 million, including support for the Western Balkans and disaster response, while reducing Turkey’s pre-accession aid by €5 million. Administrative budgets were restored, with €5.5 million added for a Conference on European Democracy. Overall commitments were set at €170.97 billion (a €2.7 billion increase from the draft budget), with payments at €159.15 billion, utilizing special instruments like the Flexibility Instrument and Contingency Margin. Gender equality, digitalization, SMEs, and cancer research were also prioritized, alongside criticism of the Commission’s cuts to Parliament’s administrative budget.

ID condemns the expansion of EU taxation powers as undemocratic overreach, directly contradicting the "no taxation without representation" principle through supranational revenue instruments lacking proper parliamentary accountability.  
ID warns against carbon border adjustment complexities that prioritize ideological environmentalism over trade realities, failing to address the issue's unrealistic revenue projections ranging from €5-14 billion.  
ID demands withdrawal from EU fiscal integration schemes, citing the UK Brexit model as preferable to becoming "taxation colonies" through shared debt obligations and resource-based levies.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the inclusion of the plastic packaging waste levy as a critical step toward sustainable EU funding, aligning with their environmental justice priorities while urging immediate expansion to tax digital giants (GAFAM) to ensure corporate accountability.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the necessity for all remaining member states to ratify the own resources agreement by April’s end, enhancing the Recovery Fund’s capacity to address post-pandemic socioeconomic inequalities as outlined in their 2023 fiscal equity agenda.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4 to mandate stricter timelines for implementing the financial transaction tax and EU-wide minimum corporate taxation, ensuring the issue fully addresses systemic tax avoidance by multinationals.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s parliamentary oversight provisions but recommends reinforcing transparency mechanisms in Recital 12 to audit member states’ compliance with anti-tax haven commitments.  
GUE_NGL warns that delays in operationalizing own resources risk replicating the EU’s vaccine rollout failures, urging accelerated ratification to prevent further erosion of public trust in EU institutions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and approved the amended Council draft on the EU’s system of own resources, emphasizing alignment with the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and reforms to ensure sustainable funding. It stressed adherence to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020, which outlines budgetary discipline, cooperation, and a roadmap for introducing new own resources, including potential revenue streams to repay EU debt from the recovery instrument. The resolution reiterated Parliament’s longstanding demands for sufficient funding to meet citizens’ expectations, referencing prior positions from 2018 to 2020 on MFF adequacy, equitable burden-sharing, and transparency. It approved amendments to specific articles and recitals of the draft regulation, focusing on clarifying implementation timelines, ensuring alignment with existing treaties, and reinforcing parliamentary oversight. Parliament insisted the Council notify it of any deviations from the approved text and consult again if proposing substantial changes, underscoring the need for continued collaboration in budgetary matters while safeguarding institutional prerogatives.

title: Council regulation laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2021 to 2027: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2021 to 2027 | A9-0260/2020 | European Parliament

The Parliament will discuss adopting the budget regulation balancing fiscal priorities, recovery funding allocation, and institutional accountability mechanisms.

EPP absolutely agrees the rule of law conditionality mechanism as a historic achievement that perfectly aligns with their commitment to upholding EU foundational values.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of youth employment and green/digital transitions through the €1.8 trillion framework, reflecting their manifesto goals for generational equity.  
EPP absolutely agrees the Commission's independent application of budgetary safeguards, ensuring strict adherence to rule of law principles without political interference.  
EPP strongly advocates the solidarity-driven recovery model, recognizing the German Presidency's pivotal role in achieving cross-national consensus on EU budgetary unity.  
EPP absolutely agrees transparent fund allocation systems that protect EU financial interests, aligning with their longstanding advocacy for accountable expenditure controls.

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the prioritization of biodiversity protection as a standalone budgetary objective, ensuring nature restoration receives dedicated funding streams beyond climate accounting.  
GREEN_EFA totally accepts the Parliament’s reinforced role in MFF oversight, particularly in scrutinizing emergency measures under Article 122 TFEU to prevent budgetary misuse.

ECR supports the MFF's future-oriented programs in education and innovation while advising stronger emphasis on sector-specific flexibility for climate targets, particularly regarding the 55% CO₂ reduction impact assessments.  
ECR highlights the need to align COVID-19 recovery fund allocations with Article 122 TFEU's original intent, proposing amendments to prevent unconditional transfers unrelated to pandemic relief.  
ECR advises reinforcing parliamentary oversight of EU borrowing under Article 311 TFEU to safeguard fiscal responsibility and taxpayer interests, citing national audit warnings.  
ECR endorses cross-border infrastructure investments like Rail Baltica but urges treaty-compliant implementation to avoid disproportionate liabilities for smaller member states.  
ECR requests delaying the rule of law conditionality mechanism until the European Court of Justice clarifies its conformity with treaties, ensuring equal sovereignty principles.

ID rejects the MFF's erosion of national budgetary autonomy through centralized EU tax mechanisms, directly conflicting with ID's foundational principle of preserving member states' fiscal sovereignty.  
ID opposes the rule of law conditionality framework as an unconstitutional coercion tool, aligning with ID's stance against political blackmail disguised as institutional oversight.  
ID condemns the generational debt burden created by mutualized borrowing, fundamentally contradicting ID's commitment to fiscal responsibility and treaty compliance under Article 125 TFEU.  
ID challenges the undemocratic acceleration of federalism through direct EU revenue streams, rejecting this supranational power grab that bypasses national ratification processes.  
ID denounces the issue's disregard for treaty-mandated unanimity requirements, upholding ID's position that major fiscal decisions must protect minority state interests through veto rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework (MFF) for 2021-2027, endorsing the budgetary framework and its annexes. It approved joint declarations with the Council and the Commission, emphasizing interinstitutional commitments to budgetary scrutiny, particularly for measures under Article 122 TFEU that could impact the EU budget. The resolution also endorsed Parliament’s own declaration, reaffirming priorities from earlier resolutions on the MFF, including citizen-focused funding and addressing gaps identified during the COVID-19 crisis. It acknowledged Commission declarations annexed to the resolution, signaling alignment on procedural and policy continuity. The resolution underscored the legal basis of the MFF under Article 312 TFEU and Euratom Treaty provisions, while omitting specific numerical allocations but implicitly upholding the 2021-2027 timeline and structural priorities outlined in previous parliamentary positions.

title: Motions for resolutions - MFF, Rule of Law Conditionality and Own Resources: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, the InterInstitutional Agreement, the EU Recovery Instrument and the Rule of Law Regulation | B9-0428/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic caused severe socio-economic disruption across the EU, delaying negotiations on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and Recovery Instrument due to disagreements over rule-of-law conditionality and budget allocations. The Parliament will discuss the adoption of the MFF, Recovery Instrument, and related rule-of-law regulation to address crisis recovery and EU budgetary governance.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely upholds the Rule of Law Regulation as a historic achievement that perfectly aligns with its commitment to defending EU values and ensuring taxpayer funds protect democratic principles.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on unconditional application of rule of law conditionality from 1 January 2021, asserting the legal text's clarity without need for additional guidelines.  
EPP absolutely upholds the Commission's independent enforcement role, emphasizing that only the Court of Justice holds interpretive authority over EU legislation.  
EPP applauds the German Presidency's leadership in securing the agreement, recognizing it as vital for maintaining European solidarity and overcoming national egoism in budget allocation.

SD totally approves the unconditional application of the Rule of Law Regulation from 1 January 2021, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to safeguarding EU values and preventing misuse of taxpayer funds.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's climate ambition through its insistence on maintaining Parliament's 60% emissions reduction target while welcoming the Council's 55% compromise as a baseline for further action.  
SD totally approves the historic debt mutualization through Next Generation EU, recognizing this as a transformative step toward economic solidarity that rejects austerity frameworks from previous crises.  
SD perfectly supports the rejection of Council attempts to delay rule-of-law enforcement, demanding immediate Commission activation of conditionality mechanisms without awaiting CJEU rulings.  
SD totally approves enhanced parliamentary oversight of recovery fund implementation, ensuring alignment with SD priorities for green/digital transitions and social equality across all Member States.

GREEN_EFA totally advocates the issue’s insistence on unconditional application of the Rule of Law Regulation from 1 January 2021, perfectly aligning with their commitment to safeguarding EU values against systemic democratic backsliding.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the rejection of Council attempts to reinterpret legislation, affirming that only the Court of Justice holds interpretive authority and that political declarations cannot dilute co-legislated texts.  

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s climate provisions, particularly the 30% climate spending target and biodiversity safeguards, while emphasizing that the -55% emissions reduction net target must serve as a floor for future increases to meet scientific imperatives.  

GREEN_EFA totally advocates the imperative for the Commission to act immediately on rule-of-law breaches without awaiting guidelines, aligning with their demand for unwavering enforcement of conditionality to protect EU funds from misuse.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s condemnation of unanimity rule obstacles, perfectly reflecting their advocacy for treaty reform to prevent minority vetoes on critical democratic and climate priorities.

ECR rejects the Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation as an unlawful political instrument that violates treaty principles of national sovereignty and equal dignity among member states.  
ECR opposes the EU Recovery Instrument’s legal basis, condemning its reliance on Article 122 as a distortion of treaty provisions intended for emergency disasters, not unconditional fiscal transfers.  
ECR entirely againsts with the issue’s climate targets, citing the lack of sectoral impact assessments and failure to account for regional disparities like Flanders’ industrial needs.  
ECR condemns the debt burden imposed by the Recovery Fund, arguing it irresponsibly mortgages future generations without enforceable repayment mechanisms or spending conditionality.  
ECR asserts the issue overlooks critical treaty violations, particularly the EU’s encroachment on member states’ constitutional autonomy to define judicial systems and policy priorities.

ID completely opposes the Rule of Law Regulation as a political blackmail tool that undermines national sovereignty and democratic decision-making through unanimity.  
ID rejects the unprecedented debt mutualization and fiscal transfers of the recovery package, warning it creates unsustainable financial obligations and violates EU treaty provisions.  
ID condemns the federalist agenda behind new EU taxes and own resources, viewing this as an unconstitutional power grab that transforms the EU into a centralized superstate.  
ID demands full transparency on recovery fund allocations and conditionalities, exposing the false promise of net benefits for member states through complex financial mechanisms.  
ID exposes hypocrisy in applying rule of law conditionality while ignoring human rights violations by EU-favored regimes, demonstrating selective enforcement of values.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key decisions regarding the EU’s response to the COVID-19 crisis, the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027, and the Rule of Law Regulation. It welcomed the historic political agreements reached in November 2020, including the MFF, the Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA), the EU Recovery Instrument (EURI), and the Rule of Law Regulation, which aim to address the pandemic’s socio-economic impacts, support the Green Deal, digital transition, and protect EU values and taxpayer funds. The Parliament emphasized the necessity of linking EU budget access to adherence to the rule of law, stressing that the Rule of Law Regulation must apply unconditionally from 1 January 2021 without requiring additional guidelines, as its legal text is sufficiently clear. It criticized delays caused by the unanimity rule in the Council, which hindered timely adoption of the package, and rejected attempts by the European Council to interpret legislation, asserting that only the Court of Justice holds interpretive authority. The resolution underscored the Commission’s obligation to enforce EU law independently, including defending the Rule of Law Regulation against potential legal challenges, and affirmed Parliament’s readiness to use legal tools, such as Article 265 TFEU, to ensure compliance. It also highlighted the need for enhanced parliamentary oversight of the Next Generation EU recovery fund and called for addressing unanimity requirements in the upcoming Conference on the Future of Europe to streamline decision-making.

title: Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 and own resources: time to meet citizens' expectations: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework and own resources: time to meet citizens’ expectations | B9-0110/2019 | European Parliament
background: The European Commission’s 2018 proposals for the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and own resources system, alongside the UK’s impending withdrawal, necessitated adjustments to EU budget priorities addressing climate action, migration, and defense under Treaty obligations, with the current MFF expiring in 2020. The Parliament will discuss the MFF and own resources reform.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions maintaining cohesion and agricultural funding as essential for regional stability and rural development, aligning with the issue's priorities.  
EPP approves the proposed new own resources including digital services and carbon taxes to ensure sustainable EU financing without excessive national transfers.  
EPP urges immediate political commitment to finalize the MFF, warning that delays jeopardize Erasmus+, research, and agricultural beneficiaries across Europe.  
The issue's climate mainstreaming requirements align perfectly with EPP's commitment to transparent, measurable environmental investments in all EU policies.  
EPP proposes enhancing budget efficiency measures to ensure member state contributions remain proportional while funding new priorities like digital transition.

SD strongly upholds the issue's proposed €1.3% GNI budget ceiling as essential for maintaining robust cohesion and agricultural funding while advancing climate neutrality, aligning with SD's commitment to social justice and green transition.  
SD approves integrating rule-of-law conditionality to protect EU funds, proposing enhanced transparency metrics to track climate spending effectiveness without opposing the core mechanism.  
SD endorses establishing new own resources through digital taxation and carbon border adjustments, urging accelerated legislative proposals to match von der Leyen's commitments on EU fiscal integration.  
SD emphasizes strengthening rural investment safeguards in cohesion policy to prevent Euroscepticism, enhancing agricultural subsidies in line with Mercosur competition challenges as a budget enhancement priority.  
SD welcomes Parliament's insistence on trilateral negotiations to prevent funding gaps, advocating strict application of SDG mainstreaming across all programs to meet citizens' regional development expectations.

RENEW supports the proposed MFF's focus on climate action and digitalization as essential to advancing RENEW's priorities for a sustainable and competitive Europe.  
RENEW proposes amending Article 8 to require quarterly Commission reporting on climate expenditure tracking methodologies, ensuring accountability in meeting the 30% spending target.  
RENEW advises accelerating the introduction of new own resources by setting a binding 2023 implementation deadline for the carbon border adjustment mechanism.  
RENEW expresses concern that maintaining cohesion funding at current levels without reallocating from outdated agricultural subsidies risks underfunding urban innovation clusters.  
RENEW endorses the rule-of-law conditionality but recommends annual independent audits of judicial independence benchmarks to strengthen enforcement.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on climate mainstreaming, particularly its demand for transparent methodologies and parliamentary oversight to ensure 30% of spending directly targets climate action, aligning with the party’s climate neutrality roadmap.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees the call for new own resources such as a carbon border adjustment mechanism and digital tax, proposing to accelerate their implementation to fund the European Green Deal without compromising social investments.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the rejection of austerity-driven budget cuts, emphasizing that maintaining cohesion funds while redirecting agricultural subsidies toward sustainable practices reflects their vision of a socially just ecological transition.  
GREEN_EFA urges enhancing the rule-of-law conditionality to explicitly link funding to member states’ compliance with climate targets, transforming the mechanism into a dual safeguard for democracy and environmental commitments.  
GREEN_EFA suggests amending the issue to include quantified annual benchmarks for climate-related expenditures, ensuring accountability beyond the 30% target while maintaining strong support for the overall ambition.

ECR slightly sanctions the MFF contingency plan extension mechanism but demands revisions to Article 7 to prevent disproportionate fund reallocation from cohesion programs.  
ECR opposes the proposed cohesion budget reductions as inconsistent with its principle of territorial equity, urging amendments to Clause 12(b) to maintain binding minimum allocations for less-developed regions.  
ECR rejects the migration integration funding framework in Section 9, arguing it overlooks critical aspects of demographic stability in peripheral member states like Croatia.  
ECR requests restructuring the "new own resources" system under Protocol 28 compliance checks, citing regressive impacts on national fiscal sovereignty in smaller economies.  
ECR warns the current climate mainstreaming methodology fails to address rural development trade-offs, requiring explicit safeguards for agricultural competitiveness in Annex 3.

ID rejects the proposed €1.3 trillion budget increase as absolutely condemning with ID's principle of fiscal restraint and national sovereignty over spending priorities.  
ID opposes the creation of EU-wide taxes through "own resources," denouncing carbon border adjustments and digital levies as illegitimate bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity.  
ID condemns the issue's conditional funding mechanisms as antidemocratic tools enabling Brussels to politically punish member states through budget allocations.  
ID challenges the climate spending mandates as economically destructive to European industries while failing to address global competitors' environmental practices.  
ID warns that Germany's disproportionate financial burden – exacerbated by Brexit contributions – violates fair burden-sharing and amplifies existing Eurozone subsidy imbalances.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a robust 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) aligned with EU political priorities, proposing a budget of €1,324.1 billion (1.3% of EU-27 gross national income) to address challenges such as climate change, youth empowerment, research, digitalization, social rights, migration, and defense. It emphasized boosting flagship programs while maintaining cohesion, agriculture, and fisheries funding, and integrating the UN Sustainable Development Goals, climate action, and gender equality across all policies. The resolution demanded a reformed EU revenue system, including new own resources such as a carbon border adjustment mechanism, digital services tax, and financial transaction tax, while abolishing rebates and simplifying VAT. It insisted on a rule-of-law mechanism to protect the EU budget from systemic violations of EU values. The Parliament criticized the Council’s delays in negotiations, called for immediate trilateral talks, and urged the Commission to propose an MFF contingency plan by early 2020 to extend current funding ceilings if needed, preventing program disruptions. It welcomed the incoming Commission’s commitments, including the European Green Deal, but stressed that new initiatives must not compromise the MFF’s ambition, warning against reduced funding as a setback. Climate mainstreaming was underscored as essential, requiring transparent methodologies and Parliament’s involvement in tracking climate-related spending. The resolution reaffirmed Parliament’s refusal to approve any MFF that undermines its legislative role or EU added value, stressing solidarity and efficiency through pooled resources.

title: System of own resources of the European Union: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation laying down implementing measures for the system of own resources of the European Union and repealing Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 608/2014 | A9-0047/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic's economic impact prompted the EU to establish the Next Generation EU recovery instrument, necessitating borrowing against future budgets. Existing EU financing relied on member state contributions (VAT, GNI) under a 2014 framework. The Parliament will discuss reforms to the EU's own resources system to fund recovery commitments and long-term budgetary sustainability.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely supports the swift ratification of the own resources decision as critical to delivering the €750 billion recovery package, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to economic stability and crisis response.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on sustainable revenue streams that avoid burdening national budgets, reflecting EPP's climate transition priorities through plastic waste contributions and green taxation mechanisms.  
EPP entirely supports the harmonized VAT calculation reforms as essential modernization of EU financing, advancing EPP's agenda for simplified fiscal governance across member states.  
EPP entirely supports linking new own resources to digital taxation and emissions trading systems, consistent with EPP's 2020 roadmap for equitable corporate contributions to EU priorities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the urgency of operationalizing NextGenerationEU funding by summer 2021, upholding EPP's principle that visible recovery outcomes reinforce public trust in European integration.

SD entirely approves the roadmap for new own resources targeting polluting industries and digital multinationals, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to climate justice and fair taxation.  
SD perfectly aligns with the urgency of ratifying the own resources system across all Member States to safeguard economic recovery and European unity against fragmentation risks.  
SD unequivocally supports shifting EU financing beyond RNB-based contributions, advancing SD's priority to replace fiscal austerity debates with strategic geopolitical ambition.  
SD champions the plastic packaging levy as a transformative first step toward establishing the EU as a global fiscal actor in environmental policy, consistent with the Green Deal imperatives.  
SD emphasizes the critical linkage between new revenue streams and debt sustainability for NextGenerationEU, ensuring future generations inherit robust public investment capacity rather than fiscal burdens.

GREEN_EFA totally endorses the issue's commitment to replacing national contributions with genuine EU-owned revenue streams, perfectly aligning with their decades-long campaign against budgetary dependence on member state negotiations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the binding roadmap for new own resources, particularly endorsing the proposed plastics tax as a critical first step toward making polluters finance Europe's ecological transition.  
GREEN_EFA strongly approves the integration of NextGenerationEU borrowing into the permanent framework, viewing this as foundational for future climate crisis responses despite initial COVID-specific design.  
GREEN_EFA applauds Article 10's governance structure as effectively advancing their vision of parliamentary sovereignty over EU finances, ending the "democratic anomaly" of revenue control by national capitals.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue's alignment with their 2020 demands for tech sector contributions and carbon border mechanisms, urging swift implementation to fund social-ecological priorities without austerity.

ECR conditionally endorses the regulation but opposes the introduction of EU-specific taxes like the plastic levy and CO2 mechanisms, citing disproportionate burdens on less affluent member states.  
ECR requests revisions to prioritize revenue from multinational corporations and financial institutions benefiting from the single market rather than sectoral environmental charges.  
This firmly challenges with ECR's position that taxation authority must remain exclusively with member states under EU treaty frameworks.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of spending efficiency, failing to address bureaucratic bloat or reallocation of existing budgets as prerequisites for new revenue streams.  
ECR objects to the CO2 contribution model's inequitable impact, noting Poland's projected increase from 3.5% to 11% of contributions under the new system.

ID rejects the introduction of EU-wide taxes as a federalist overreach that absolutely rejects with national sovereignty principles, particularly opposing the mutualized debt structure and Brussels’ expanded budgetary control.  
ID opposes the carbon border adjustment mechanism’s complexity and unreliable revenue projections, citing its inconsistency with fiscal responsibility and failure to address member states’ autonomy in trade policy.  
ID condemns the retroactive plastic tax as a symbol of EU financial mismanagement, arguing it overlooks critical national budgetary priorities while creating permanent fiscal obligations for states like France.  
ID fundamentally disputes the democratic legitimacy of EU tax authority, echoing historical “no taxation without representation” concerns and warning of public backlash against Brussels’ expanding fiscal colonialism.  
ID declares complete incompatibility with the issue’s debt mutualization framework, viewing Article 10’s joint repayment obligations as irreversible steps toward a transfer union that violates subsidiarity.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the draft regulation’s alignment with the Recovery Fund and multiannual financial framework, effectively advancing their priority of sustainable EU funding for economic and social revitalization.  
GUE_NGL endorses the plastic tax as a critical step and proposes amending Article 10 to explicitly mandate a digital tax on tech giants (GAFAM), ensuring multinational corporations contribute equitably.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency for all member states—particularly those in Northern and Central Europe—to ratify the agreement by April’s deadline to prevent delays in deploying recovery instruments.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s potential to reinforce fiscal justice, urging implementation mechanisms that prioritize taxing corporations and high-net-worth individuals over workers.  
GUE_NGL commends the roadmap for new own resources as aligning with their commitment to EU financial autonomy, crucial for addressing climate transition and post-pandemic challenges.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council regulation (10045/2020) on the EU’s system of own resources, aligning with the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020 on budgetary discipline, cooperation, and the introduction of new own resources, including a roadmap for their implementation. The resolution emphasized the importance of the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and recovery plans, referencing prior parliamentary positions from 2018 to 2020 that called for reforms to ensure adequate funding for EU priorities and citizens’ needs. It endorsed Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053, particularly Article 10, which governs the own resources system, and reiterated the need for a sustainable financial framework to address challenges such as economic recovery and climate transition. The Parliament instructed its President to communicate this decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring the urgency of finalizing the MFF and associated recovery instruments to meet EU objectives effectively.

title: The creation of guidelines for the application of the general regime of conditionality for the protection of the Union budget: REPORT on the creation of guidelines for the application of the general regime of conditionality for the protection of the Union budget | A9-0226/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU adopted Regulation 2020/2092 linking budget access to rule of law compliance, effective January 2021, following negotiations on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and recovery instruments. The Commission delayed implementation, citing non-binding European Council conclusions to develop guidelines. The Parliament will discuss procedural and operational challenges in applying the Regulation’s conditionality mechanism.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly agrees the issue's insistence on immediate enforcement of the rule of law conditionality mechanism, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to safeguarding EU funds through judicial integrity and anti-corruption frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for proportionality in sanctions to protect legitimate beneficiaries, reflecting EPP's priority of balancing budgetary accountability with operational fairness in cohesion policy implementation.  
EPP firmly agrees the call for transparent investigations into systemic breaches like judicial interference, effectively advancing EPP's manifesto principle that EU financing must require irreversible democratic safeguards.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on binding enforcement without supplementary guidelines, reinforcing EPP's position that the Regulation's clarity leaves no room for procedural delays compromising financial oversight.  
EPP firmly agrees integrating whistleblower protections into complaint mechanisms, mirroring EPP's 2021 rule of law action plan to empower civic oversight of EU budgetary integrity.

SD entirely promotes the immediate enforcement of the Regulation without non-binding guidelines, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to upholding rule of law as an unconditional requirement for EU fund access.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s urgency in addressing systemic corruption risks, emphasizing that delayed action on rule of law breaches directly undermines the integrity of €1.8 trillion in recovery funds.  
SD entirely promotes the proportionality principle ensuring end beneficiaries retain rights, as articulated in Kohut’s clarification that sanctions target violating governments, not citizens or legitimate entities.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for transparent Commission investigations into judicial independence threats, mirroring Marques’ insistence on avoiding procedural delays that dilute the Regulation’s binding force.  
SD entirely promotes the complaint mechanism’s alignment with whistleblower protections, reflecting Heinäluoma’s call to prevent autocratic narratives from distorting the link between values and budgetary accountability.

GREEN_EFA firmly approves the issue’s insistence on immediate enforcement of the conditionality mechanism, perfectly aligning with their unwavering stance against systemic corruption and erosion of judicial independence.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for transparency and regular reporting, recognizing these as essential to safeguarding EU funds from misuse by authoritarian regimes that undermine press freedom and democratic checks.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of activating the Regulation to halt the diversion of recovery funds to oligarchic networks, a critical step to protect Hungarian citizens and EU taxpayers alike.  
GREEN_EFA champions the call for a robust complaint mechanism, ensuring civil society can expose breaches without fear, thereby advancing their commitment to whistleblower protections and participatory democracy.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on proportionality, ensuring sanctions target corrupt elites while preserving access to funds for legitimate beneficiaries who uphold EU values.

ECR rejects the issue's selective application to Poland and Hungary as inconsistent with equal treatment principles, citing unaddressed rule of law concerns in Spain and France.  
ECR opposes the mechanism's enforcement before ECJ adjudication, completely conflicting with ECR's stance on respecting judicial due process.  
ECR condemns the proposal's double standards for overlooking systemic breaches like Dutch fishing quota fraud while targeting Central European states.  
ECR disputes allegations of financial mismanagement, emphasizing Poland's 60% absorption rate of EU funds without corruption as proof of compliance.  
ECR challenges the regulation's legitimacy, arguing it violates subsidiarity by imposing politically motivated interpretations of rule of law over national sovereignty.

ID rejects the regulation as an unlawful overreach that violates member states' sovereignty by attempting to impose contested moral values under the guise of rule of law enforcement.  
ID opposes the conditionality mechanism's application while court challenges by Poland and Hungary remain pending, denouncing it as procedurally premature and politically targeted.  
ID fundamentally disputes the legal basis of Article 2 TUE for budget sanctions, arguing treaty provisions require Article 7 procedures for systemic rule of law violations.  
ID condemns the issue's moral imperialism seeking to dismantle traditional family values protected by sovereign nations like Hungary through financial coercion.  
ID warns this mechanism sets dangerous precedent for political blackmail against any member state resisting centralized EU ideological agendas.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the immediate application of the conditionality regulation, emphasizing that the existing legal text provides sufficient clarity without requiring non-binding guidelines from the Commission. This aligns perfectly with GUE_NGL's longstanding commitment to enforcing accountability mechanisms that protect EU funds from systemic rule of law breaches.  

GUE_NGL approves the issue’s urgency in linking the €1.8 trillion recovery package to rule of law compliance, noting that delays in implementation fundamentally undermine public trust in EU institutions. The issue effectively advances GUE_NGL's priority of preventing misuse of recovery funds through robust conditionality tools.  

GUE_NGL urges enhanced transparency measures by proposing a standardized format for the Commission’s quarterly reporting to Parliament, ensuring granular tracking of investigations into judicial independence threats and corruption cases affecting EU financial interests.  

GUE_NGL applauds the requirement for cooperation with OLAF and EPPO as matching their 2021 policy framework on combating cross-border fraud, while suggesting the complaint mechanism explicitly reference civil society organizations’ role in monitoring fund allocation.  

GUE_NGL demands strict adherence to the October 2021 reporting deadline as a baseline expectation, rejecting any tolerance for bureaucratic delays in exposing member states’ systemic violations of EU values.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over delays in applying the Regulation on conditionality linking EU funds to rule of law compliance, emphasizing its binding nature since 1 January 2021 and its critical role in safeguarding the unprecedented €1.8 trillion 2021-2027 MFF and Next Generation EU recovery package. It criticized the Commission for developing non-binding guidelines, arguing the Regulation’s text is clear and requires no further interpretation, and condemned the Commission’s failure to meet Parliament’s 1 June 2021 deadline for action. The resolution stressed the need for swift, impartial investigations into systemic rule of law breaches—such as threats to judicial independence, corruption, or misuse of funds—that directly risk EU financial interests, citing examples from the Commission’s 2020 Rule of Law Report. It called for transparency, regular reporting to Parliament starting by October 2021, and cooperation with OLAF and the EPPO to address issues like non-compliance with anti-fraud recommendations. The Parliament highlighted the Regulation’s unique scope to address both individual and systemic breaches across all EU funds, urging proportionality in measures while protecting legitimate beneficiaries’ rights. It demanded clarity on criteria for systemic breaches, timely enforcement of sanctions, and a user-friendly complaint mechanism for citizens and civil society to report violations, ensuring alignment with Directive 2019/1937 on whistleblower protection. The resolution underscored the Regulation’s role in complementing existing tools to uphold EU values and financial integrity.

title: The revision of the Financial Regulation in view of the entry into force of the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework: REPORT on the revision of the Financial Regulation in view of the entry into force of the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework | A9-0295/2021 | European Parliament
background: The 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and NextGenerationEU's implementation required alignment with updated EU financial rules, following the 2018 Financial Regulation revision. COVID-19 recovery measures, including the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and new budgetary instruments necessitated adjustments to ensure transparent fund management and rule-of-law compliance. The Parliament will discuss revising the Financial Regulation to address these institutional and operational challenges.

stances.stance:

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to revise the Financial Regulation to align with the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and NextGenerationEU (NGEU), emphasizing enhanced transparency, democratic accountability, and oversight of off-budget instruments like external assigned revenue and borrowing operations. It stressed integrating the rule-of-law conditionality mechanism into the Financial Regulation to safeguard EU funds from misuse, corruption, or breaches of EU values, and called for stricter public procurement rules to prevent conflicts of interest. The resolution highlighted concerns over limited parliamentary scrutiny in crisis mechanisms under Article 122 TFEU and urged consolidating off-budget items into the EU budget for audit and discharge purposes. It advocated for a centralized, interoperable EU database to track beneficiaries and beneficial owners of funds, mandating machine-readable data to combat fraud, alongside compulsory use of risk-scoring tools like ARACHNE and harmonizing exclusion criteria across management modes. The Parliament underscored gender mainstreaming (noting only 21.7% of past programs had gender indicators) and climate action, reiterating the commitment to allocate 30% of MFF and NGEU funds to climate objectives. It pushed for simplified procedures to improve SME access, stricter audit timelines, and reforms to trust fund governance to ensure parliamentary oversight. Additionally, the resolution called for aligning procurement rules with EU strategic interests, including social and environmental goals, and urged robust methodologies to track biodiversity and climate spending while enforcing the "do no significant harm" principle.
